What is the older ずる form of modern じる verbs, as regards its usage? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;still used⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > but somewhat rarely </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > <iframe scrollbar="no" src="https://samswartzberg.com/trendquery.html?query=感ずる,感じる"></iframe> </div> </div> Modern single on'yomi + じる come from a shift from what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+; single on'yomi + ずる⟯ In the past in japanese, what is する today was... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;す⟯ How does on'yomi + じる relate to single on'yomi + ずる? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;The じる form is a modern shift from an older ずる form⟯ <div class='c2-f'> What is this an older-ish form of? </div><div class='c1-f'> What is the older-ish form of this? </div>⟮c+;　感（かん）ずる⟯|⟮c+;　感（かん）じる⟯
What kind of word class are japanese verbs sometimes/often said to be? (but probably/perhaps falsely) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Closed word classes⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > e.g.  <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japanese_grammar#Word_class_system">Wikipedia</a> </div> </div>
What do words such as ググる, スタバる and humorous coinages such as クッキングる provide some evidence against? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;That verbs in japanese are closed word classes⟯
⟮c+; スタバ⟯|⟮c+;starbucks (short)⟯
⟮c+;スタバる⟯|⟮c+;to go to starbucks⟯
⟮c+;スターバックス⟯|⟮c+;starbucks (long)⟯
⟮c+;メモる:: 3 kana ⟯|⟮c+;take notes⟯<div class="sub">  </div>
⟮c+;ミス⟯|⟮c+;mistake; error; failure (also Ms.)⟯
⟮c+;ミスる:: 3 kana ⟯|⟮c+;to make a mistake⟯<div class="sub">  </div>
⟮c+;ダブル⟯|⟮c+;double, double (of sth)⟯
⟮c+;ダブる⟯|⟮c+;to duplicate, coincide, repeat⟯
<div class='c2-f'> Alternative spelling? </div><div class='c1-f'> Pun-based reading? </div>⟮c+; ダブル⟯|⟮c+;W⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> Pun on the reading of W (ダブリュー) </div> </div>
⟮c+;　弱（よわ）み:: 1 kanji 1 kana, kana starts w m sound ⟯|⟮c+;weakness, vulnerable point, shortcoming⟯<div class="sub">  </div> ⟮c+;　強（つよ）み⟯|⟮c+;forte; strong point​⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 1 kanji 1 kana </div> </div>
⟮c+;　強（つよ）める⟯|⟮c+;strengthen を⟯ ⟮c+;　強（つよ）まる⟯|⟮c+;get strong が⟯ ⟮c+;　弱（よわ）める⟯|⟮c+;weaken を⟯ ⟮c+;　弱（よわ）まる⟯|⟮c+;weaken, abate が⟯
⟮c+;　弱（よわ）る:: 1 kanji 1 kana ⟯|⟮c+;weaken, be troubled, dejected, to be in a bind / at a loss⟯<div class="sub">  </div>
What is the phenomenon of が being replaced by の in relative clauses known as in the academic world? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;ga/no (nominative/genitive) conversion (GNC)⟯ In which relative clauses can you replace が with の? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Most, but it's unclear where the exceptions are exactly⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > ga/no conversion (GNC) </div> </div> <div class='c1-f'> which of these ga's could be replaced by no? </div>ジョンが背が高い理由  <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;both of them⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > ga/no conversion (GNC) </div> </div> <div class='c1-f'> Why is this no and not ga? </div>太郎は昨日花子<b>の</b>読んだ本を借りた <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;ga/no conversion (GNC)⟯ <div class='c1-f'> Why can't you use の to mark the subject here? </div>太郎が映画を見た <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;because it's a main clause⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > ga/no conversion (GNC) </div> </div> <div class='c1-f'> Why can you replace ga with no here? </div>太郎は気温<b>が</b>高い国へ行った <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;because it's a relative clause⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > ga/no conversion (GNC) </div> </div> <div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>ジョンの買った本  <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;The book (that) John bought⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > ga/no conversion (GNC) </div> </div> <div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>ジョンの背の高い理由 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;The reason john is tall⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > ga/no conversion (GNC) </div> </div> <div class='c1-f'> What could you use here, besides ga? </div>太郎は気温<b>が</b>高い国へ行った <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;の⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > ga/no conversion (GNC) </div> </div> In relative sentences, what can が be replaced with (most of the time)? ⟮c+;　幸福（こうふく）の　科学（かがく）⟯|⟮c+;___ formerly known as <span class="all-scr">The Institute for Research in in Human Happiness</span>, is a controversial new religious and spiritual movement, founded in Japan on 6 October 1986 by Ryuho Okawa, which has been characterized as a cult.⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> Happy Science worships a deity named El Cantare who they believe is the "Highest God of Earth, the Lord of all gods". They believe that the being was first born on Earth 330 million years ago and that it is the same entity that has been worshipped at different times as Elohim, Odin, Thoth, Ophealis (Osiris) Hermes and Shakyamuni Buddha, with Okawa himself as the current incarnation.[2][13]  </div><div class="sub all-b"> The group sold "spiritual vaccines" claimed to prevent and cure COVID-19, advertised virus-related blessings at rates from 100 to over US$400, and sold coronavirus-themed DVDs and CDs of Ryuho Okawa lecturing, which are claimed to boost immunity, as of April 2020. After initially defying physical distancing measures, it later closed its New York temple, and administered spiritual vaccines remotely.[19]  </div> </div>

What kind of archaic form is the き-form of い-adjectives? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the adnominal form⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> both of ク and of シク　形容詞, although the former would have ended just in き and the latter would have ended in しき </div> </div>
What kind of archaic form is the し-form of い-adjectives? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the sentence-final form/終止形⟯
What is the archaic sentence-final form of い-adjectives <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the し-form⟯
Where is the difference between the (now archaic) き-form and the し-form? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the き-form is archaic adnominal, and the し-form is archaic sentence-final&nbsp;⟯
How do you get back to the し form from modern い-adjectives (non-しい)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;replace the い with a し⟯
How do you get back to the し form from modern い-adjectives, for ...しい adjectives? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;remove the final い⟯
き form of ない? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;なき⟯
⟮c+;なし⟯ (<span class="c1-scr">in kanji: ⟮c+;無し⟯</span>) is ⟮c+;the classic 終止形⟯ of ⟮c+;ない⟯, meaning <span class="c1-scr c2-scr c3-scr c4-scr"> either ⟮c+;without⟯ (examples: <span class="c5-scr">⟮c+;休日なしで働く 'to work without holiday'⟯</span>) , ⟮c+;not/nothing⟯ (⟮c+;the same as ない⟯, e.g. <span class="c7-scr">⟮c+;ルールなし。 '(there are) no rules'⟯</span>), or (colloquially) ⟮c+;unsatisfactory/unaccetable&nbsp;⟯.</span>
⟮c+;　光栄（こうえい）⟯|⟮c+;(an) honor⟯
⟮c+;　鼻歌（はなうた）⟯|⟮c+;humming⟯

What do most あしい adjectives have? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;a corresponding ~u verb⟯
What some verbs such as 好む or 望む have, as regards adjectives? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;a corresponding あしい (sometimes also おしい) adjective⟯
⟮c+;　栄（さか）える⟯|⟮c+;prosper, flourish, thrive が⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> This is basically the only time this is read as さか, so meh </div> </div>

Besides defining something, what is とは often used as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;a more emphatic version of と⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What would using "とは" do here? </div>あいつともう関係ない。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Add more emphasis⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why are we using とは instead of と here？ </div>過去とは違う自分 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;To add more emphasis⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What are we asking for here? </div>「原子力」とは？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;The definition/meaning of 原子力⟯
Besides a more emphatic version of と, what is とは also often used as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;To define a word/phrase⟯
What is the particle most often used for defining something? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;とは⟯
When used alone with a word/phrase, what is とは doing? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;asking for the definition of that word⟯
素数⟮c+;とは⟯何かを学んだ。
⟮c+;とは思わなかった⟯|⟮c+;Did not think that (expression)⟯
What can とは be short for? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;とは思わなかった⟯

⟮c+;　見（み）　破（やぶ）る⟯|⟮c+;see through (a plot, lie)⟯
⟮c+;　打（う）ち　破（やぶ）る⟯|⟮c+;break, smash, destroy⟯

⟮c+;　破（やぶ）く⟯|⟮c+;tear, rip を⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> in the case of 破, the ones with k as the first letter of the okurigana (that is, く and ける)&nbsp; are (generally) semantically restricted to tearing, while those with r as the first letter of the okurigana (that is, る and れる) can either have a tearing meaning, but also a meaning of breaking or defeating. The ones ending -u with one kana (that is, く and る) are intransitive (が), the ones ending -eru (that is, ける and れる) are transitive (を) </div> </div>
⟮c+;　破（やぶ）ける⟯|⟮c+;be torn, get worn out が⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> in the case of 破, the ones with k as the first letter of the okurigana (that is, く and ける)  are (generally) semantically restricted to tearing, while those with r as the first letter of the okurigana (that is, る and れる) can either have a tearing meaning, but also a meaning of breaking or defeating. The ones ending -u with one kana (that is, く and る) are intransitive (が), the ones ending -eru (that is, ける and れる) are transitive (を) </div> </div>

How can a root of a certain onomatopoeia be realized? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;In various ways⟯
How many realizations does any given onomatopoeitic root have? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;depends on the root&nbsp;⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > 1 to many </div> </div>
<div class='c2-f'> What implication does a realization of an onomatopoeitic root in this way have, in general? </div><div class='c1-f'> What realization of an onomatopoeitic root generates this implication, in general? </div>⟮c+;root + っ(と)⟯|⟮c+;sudden, abrupt⟯
<div class='c2-f'> What implication does a realization of an onomatopoeitic root in this way have, in general? </div><div class='c1-f'> What realization of an onomatopoeitic root generates this implication, in general? </div>⟮c+;root + root (reduplication)⟯|⟮c+;happens repeatedly⟯
for a single root of onomatopoeia, what can it end in, besides plainly, っ(と), and with り? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;with ん⟯
for a single root of onomatopoeia, what can it end in, besides plainly, っ(と), and with ん? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;with り⟯
What does having long vowels in your onomatopoeia imply? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;that it takes its sweet-ass time⟯
For onomatopoeia, besides the root and root+り, what can also get reduplicated? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;root+ん⟯
For onomatopoeia, besides the root and root+ん, what can also get reduplicated? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;root+り⟯
When used as a quotation, what particle is used with the onomatopoeia (generally)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;と⟯
みんなにアハハ⟮c+;と⟯笑われた。 <div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> Quotation onomatopoeia </div> </div>
When used as an adverb (but not for changes of state), what particle do onomatopoeia take, if not と? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;no particle⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > more casual </div> </div>
When used as an adverb (but not for changes of state), what particle do onomatopoeia take, if not no particle? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;と⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > less casual </div> </div>
When using onomatopoeia as adverbs (but not for changes of state), when is と omitted? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;more casual speech⟯
When using onomatopoeia as adverbs (but not for changes of state), when is と included? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;less casual speech⟯
雷がごろごろ⟮c+;と⟯鳴り始めた。 <div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> と or nothing (adverb) </div> </div>
When being used as an adverb for changes of state, what particle does an onomatopoeia take? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;に⟯
シャツがびしょびしょ⟮c+;に⟯濡れてしまった。 <div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> change of state </div> </div>
この道、がたがた⟮c+;に⟯なってるね。 <div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> change of state </div> </div>
お気に入りのシャツがぼろぼろ⟮c+;に⟯なってしまった。 <div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> change of state </div> </div>
If we want to express the idea of doing an onomatopoeia, what do we add after the onomatopoeia？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;する/やる⟯
汗で下着がじめじめ⟮c+;して⟯いて気持ちが悪い。 <div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> perhaps also やって, although probably not </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > My underwear is soaked in sweat and it feels gross. </div> </div>
なんだか、喉がいがいが⟮c+;する⟯。 <div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> probably also だ and perhaps perhaps, やる, although probably not </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > My throat feels a little sore. </div> </div>
たまにはこうやってみんなで集まってわいわい⟮c+;やる⟯のもいいよね。 <div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> perhaps also する </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > It's nice to get together with everyone and be raucous like this sometimes. </div> </div>
How would we express that something <b>is</b>&nbsp;a onomatopoeia? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;as normal with the compula⟯
このまくら、ぐにゃぐにゃ⟮c+;だ⟯よ! <div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > This pillow is so squishy! </div> </div>
徹夜続きでくたくた⟮c+;だ⟯。 <div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> general predication </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I'm exhausted from being up all night. </div> </div>
「ニコニコ⟮c+;する⟯なっ！ここは陸軍だ！マクドナルドじゃねえぞっ！」<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> perhaps also やる </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > "Don't be smiling! This is the Army, not McDonald's!" </div> </div>
What is sometimes used together with an onomatopoeia, to express some kind of reaction? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;来る⟯
ぼくにはしっくり⟮c+;来ない⟯。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> onomatopoeia 来る reaction </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >       It doesn't fit well with me./It doesn't feel right to me. </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > implication of reaction </div> </div>

When attached to things, what does 　等（ら）&nbsp;gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;or so/around⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> often as ら辺 (but according to wiktionary, not always: https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%AD%89) </div><div class="sub c1-f" > not the plural marker </div> </div>

What is the most common way of pluralizing 彼女? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;彼女たち⟯

<div class='c2-f'> Kanji spelling for this pluralizing suffix? </div><div class='c1-f'> Kana for this pluralizing suffix? </div>⟮c+;ども⟯|⟮c+;共⟯<div class="sub"> <div class='sub f'> is rarely spelled in kanji though </div> </div>
What connotation does 　共（ども） as a plural marker have? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Humble⟯

⟮c+;　彼（か）:: 1 kanji made up of one kana ⟯|⟮c+;Distal demonstrative (similar to あれ)⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> generally archaic </div> </div>
⟮c+;　彼（かれ）:: 1 kanji made up of 2 kana ⟯|⟮c+;Distal demonstrative (similar to あれ)⟯<div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > not the person meaning </div> </div>
⟮c+;かの:: 2 kana ⟯|⟮c+;Distal demonstrative&nbsp; determiner (similar to あの)⟯<div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > not the person meaning </div><div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > also spelled 彼の </div> </div>
What does や do when attached to an adverb? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Add emphasis⟯
What does や to indicate emphasis attach to? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Adverbs⟯
What adverbs can you attach や to to indicate emphasis? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;only a limited set⟯
⟮c+;　又（また）もや:: 1 kanji 2 kana ⟯|⟮c+;again and again⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> や as adverb intensifier </div> </div>
⟮c+;　今（いま）や:: 1 kanji 1 kana ⟯|⟮c+;now (esp. in contrast to the past)⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> や as adverb intensifier </div> </div>
The semantic implication when using し is almost always... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;some kind of reason⟯
What is the one-character particle that almost always indicates some reason? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;し⟯
When listing reasons with し, what can you do with the final し, besides leaving it out or not leaving it out? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;replace it with から⟯
How strong does し come on? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Relatively strong⟯
What does し as a particle follow, for verbs, when not being polite? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the 終止形 (which is the 辞書形)⟯
What does し as a particle follow, for verbs, when being polite (which forms are possible)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the 終止形 (which is the 辞書形)&nbsp;or the ます-form⟯
What does し as a particle follow, for い adjectives? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the 終止形 (which is the 辞書形)⟯
What does し as a particle follow, for な adjectives? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the 終止形 (which is the 辞書形 + だ)⟯
What does し as a particle follow, for nouns? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the 終止形 (which is the 辞書形 + copula)⟯
吸う with し particle <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;吸うし⟯
幼い with し particle <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;幼いし⟯
簡単 with し particle <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;簡単だし⟯
ばか with し particle <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;馬鹿だし⟯
When listing with し, what can it sometimes indicate, in addition to reason? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;contrast⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What could you optionally add here? </div> お金もないし、車もない <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;a second し⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> as with all list particles, the last instance is optional </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > or a から </div> </div>
お金もない⟮c+;し⟯、車もない⟮c+;し⟯…<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I don't have any money, I don't have a car (,  so)... </div> </div>
綺麗だ⟮c+;し⟯、広い⟮c+;し⟯、いいね、このアパート<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > It's clean, it's spacious, this appartment is nice! (,  so I want to buy it) </div> </div>
 彼氏は、タバコも吸｛⟮c+;う⟯・⟮c+;います⟯｝し、お酒も飲みます。 <div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > 　My boyfriend smokes and drinks.  </div> </div>
その映画は見たい⟮c+;し⟯、お金はない⟮c+;し⟯、どうしよう。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> し as contrast </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > 　 I want to watch that movie, but I don't have the money...what am I going to do...  </div> </div>
歯は痛い⟮c+;し⟯、歯医者には行きたくない⟮c+;し⟯、困ったよ。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> し as contrast </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >     My teeth hurt, but I don't want to go to the doctor, I'm in a rut!  </div> </div>
台風は来る⟮c+;し⟯、仕事はある⟮c+;し⟯、本当に困ったよ。  <div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> し as contrast </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >     The typhoon's coming, but I got my job. And so, I'm really at a loss.   </div> </div>
職は失うし、妻とは別れるし（⟮c+;で⟯）、彼はひどく元気がない。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >      Losing his job, splitting up with his wife, he is really depressed.  </div> </div>
When し is used as a sentence-final particle, what is doing? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Giving a reason (for something that was said before or implied)⟯
荷物が多いし、雨も降ってきた(⟮c+;し⟯・⟮c+;から⟯・⟮c+;ø⟯)、どこかで休もうか。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > We've a lot of luggage, and it's started to rain, so shall we take a break somewhere? </div> </div>
せっかくパリまで来たんだから、観光でもしよう。天気もいい⟮c+;し⟯。
<div class='c1-f'> What is the second sentence doing here? </div>このお店はすごくおいしいですよ。かなり安いですし。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Providing additional justification&nbsp;⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What is the し doing here? </div>上海の不動産価格は去年1年間で24％増加し、今では中国で1番高くなっています。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;formal connective of する⟯
What occurrence of し might be easy to confuse with the particle し? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;し as formal connective&nbsp;⟯
How would have シク活用 adjectives ended in the 連体形 in classical japanese? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;しき⟯
How would have ク活用 adjectives ended in the 連体形 in classical japanese? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;き⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What part of words or sentences does this refer to, in a general sense? </div>　語（ご）　尾（び） <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the ending⟯
　語（ご）　尾（び） can refer to the ending of what or what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Words or sentences⟯
When 　語（ご）　尾（び） is used for sentence endings, what is it (nearly) synonymous with? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;　終（しゅう）　助（じょ）　詞（し）⟯
When 　語（ご）　尾（び） is used for sentence endings, what might be examples? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;よ, ね, etc.⟯
In international linguistic analysis, what is the ending of u-verbs considered to be? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;just /u/⟯
In international linguistic analysis, what is the ending of ru-verbs considered to be? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;<span class="ipa phoneme">ru</span>⟯
In traditional japanese grammar, what is the 　語（ご）　尾（び） of 食べる? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;べる⟯
In traditional japanese grammar, what is the 　語（ご）　幹（かん） of 食べる? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;た⟯
In traditional japanese grammar, what is the 　語（ご）　幹（かん） of 飲む? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;の⟯
What does 　語（ご）　幹（かん） gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;stem⟯ In international linguistic analysis, how is 飲む split between stem and ending? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;nom-u⟯ In international linguistic analysis, how is 食べる split between stem and ending? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;tabe-ru⟯ Besides the traditional definition, what is 　語（ご）　幹（かん） sometimes also used to refer to? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;　連（れん）　用（よう）　形（けい） in the sense of the -masu stem⟯
In traditional japanese grammar, what part of u-verbs is considered to be part of the 　語（ご）　幹（かん）? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Everything besides the final consonant + u⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > e.g. の for 飲む </div> </div>
In traditional japanese grammar, what part of ru-verbs is considered to be part of the 　語（ご）　幹（かん）? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Everything besides the Consonant + eru/iru⟯
In traditional japanese grammar, what part of ru-verbs is considered to be part of the 　語（ご）　尾（び）? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the final consonant + eru/iru⟯
In traditional japanese grammar, what part of u-verbs is considered to be part of the 　語（ご）　尾（び）? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the final consonant + u⟯
チェコ語は簡単⟮c+;だ⟯。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Czech is easy.  </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Casual, forceful-ish, copula </div> </div>
In general, what forms don't modify nouns? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Polite forms⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What's the problem here? </div>真面目でした人 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Polite forms don't generally modify nouns⟯
if an adjective ends in い, but that&nbsp; い is written in kanji, it is probably what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;A na-adjective (形容動詞)⟯
if an adjective ends in い, but is followed by だ, it is probably what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;A na-adjective (形容動詞)⟯
How can you make ではない a little more formal, but less so than ではありません? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;ではないです⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > cf. じゃないです </div> </div>
How can you make ではない somewhat more formal? (<b>suitable for writing</b>, but not 敬語) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;ではありません⟯
What forms can ある in ではない take? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;pretty much all ある forms⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > although the positive is quite rare </div> </div>
What kind of connotation does で<b>は</b>ある have? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;contrastive⟯
What does ではある roughly mean? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the same as である = copula⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > although it has a contrastive implication, due to the contrastive は </div> </div>
What does ではない work nearly parallel to？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;じゃない⟯
女性⟮c+;ではある⟯が、彼女はこのバーベルを持ち上げられる。 <div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Woman as she is, she can lift this barbell. </div><br><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > strong contrastive implication </div> </div>
彼女はせんさく好き⟮c+;ではある⟯けれども私は彼女が好きだ。 <div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > She is inquisitive, but I like her none the worse. </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > strong contrastive implication </div> </div>
学者⟮c+;ではある⟯が、彼は信頼されていない。 <div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Scholarly as he is, he can't be relied on. </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > strong contrastive implication </div> </div>
⟮c+;ノ形容詞⟯|⟮c+;no-adjective (literally)⟯
⟮c+;ナ形容詞⟯|⟮c+;na-adjective (literally)⟯
Adjectives that connect to nouns via の instead of な are called what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;ノ形容詞⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > 1 kana 3 kanji </div> </div>
How do the set of na-adjectives and the set of no-adjectives relate? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;They intersect⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > That is, there are many na-adjectives that can also be used as no-adjectives and v.v. </div> </div>
How do you turn の-adjectives into adverbs? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;add に as with な-adjectives⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this become? </div>の-adjective + に <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;An adverb⟯
how many adjectives can use both な and の to modify nouns? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;probably most な/の adjectives⟯
What is a way to look at (at least some) long compound nouns coming into being in japanese? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;の-phrases where the の is dropped⟯
What is the difference between の and な-adjectives, in terms of how they are used? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;only that one uses の and the other uses な to modify nouns⟯
For nouns that can use both な and の, what does changing from one to the other change? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the nuance/feel⟯
If both are possible, what is the difference between な and の, in particular? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;な is somewhat more softer, more personal, casual⟯
What might happen to the variability between な and の in some set phrases? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;In some set phrases, the use of な over の or v.v. may have become mandatory⟯
Besides a corresponding な-adj/な-based 連体詞, what adjective(al) form do some い-adjectives also have? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;a の-based adjective/連体詞⟯
What do most の-based 連体詞 sound like? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;archaic/literary⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What kind of 連体詞 is this? </div>　長（なが）の <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;one based on の⟯
How are 連体詞 generated from い adjectives (when they are), as to what gets removed? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the い gets removed⟯
How are most (?) 連体詞 generated from い adjectives, after the い was removed? (two options) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;な/の gets attached⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What kind of thing is 青 acting as here? </div>青の時間  <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;a ノ形容詞⟯
What could we say 青い, 青(の), 青(な) as well as e.g. 青空 share? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;a 'root'  青⟯
What is 青 doing in 青い, 青(な), 青(の), 青空?&nbsp; <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;being realized in different ways⟯
Adjective stems like 青 can be realized in a number of different ways, of which I currently know 4 (though not all adjectives can be realized in all of these ways): ⟮c+;青い⟯, ⟮c+;青(の)⟯, ⟮c+;青(な)⟯ as well as ⟮c+;青 based- compound (e.g. 青空)⟯
Negative + raised intonation =&nbsp; <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;question which presumes a positive answer⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>遅くない？ + raised intonation <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Aren't you late?⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> cf. https://ameblo.jp/hachi-yellow-rug/entry-12569681239.html for real world examples </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What's the problem here? </div>多い人 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;多い can't be in the adnominal position as-is⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What's the problem here? </div>少ない人  <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;少ない can't be in the adnominal position⟯
Where can 多い and 少ない not appear? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;In the adnominal position⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> https://www.imabi.net/ooisukunai.htm https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%B0%91%E3%81%AA%E3%81%84#Japanese </div><div class="sub all-b"> except rarely, and of course as part of modifying vps </div> </div>
Which two common words indicating amount cannot generally appear in the adnominal position? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;多い and 少ない⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> https://www.imabi.net/ooisukunai.htm https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%B0%91%E3%81%AA%E3%81%84#Japanese </div> </div>
In what way <b>can</b>&nbsp;and are 多い and 少ない often used? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;as a predicate⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Where's the problem? </div>公園にはベンチが<mark>多い</mark>です。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;There is no problem, one can use 多い as a predicate⟯
When <b>can</b>&nbsp;多い and 少ない precede nouns? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;if they're part of a modfying adnominal phrase⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > since they are then acting as a predicate </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > also rarely on their own </div> </div>
Why can 多い and 少ない precede nouns when part of a modifying verb phrase? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Because they are then acting as a predicate⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Where's the problem? </div>私はお金が<mark>少ない</mark>です。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;There is no problem⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > Is part of modifying VP and thus predicate </div> </div>
私はお⟮c+;金が少ない⟯です。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> Okay since predicate&nbsp; </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I have little money </div> </div>
What is the rare exception that allows 少ない to work in the adnominal position proper? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;When indicating sheer scarcity⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is adominal position 少ない okay here? </div>少ない給料でお金を貯める。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Because it's indicating the sheer scarcity⟯
When used in the context of quantities, where we in english would use 'little' or 'large', what words are often used in japanese? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;少ない/多い⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is this grammatical, despite the literal translation of: "Small children have few vocabulary"? </div>幼い子供は語いが少ない。  <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Because in the context of things which are quantifiable, 少ない is used even where we would say small in english⟯
ヨーロッパはアジアより人口が⟮c+;少ない⟯。 <div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> 少ない for quantifiable things where we use ’small' in english </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Europe has a smaller population than Asia. </div> </div>
For what kind of things do you use 少ない, where in english you would use 'small'? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Things that are quantifiable⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > vocabulary (=amount of voc items), portion (=amount of food in a portion), ... </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> Why is 多い being used here? </div> シアトルでは雨が多いです。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Because 多い/少ない is often used for frequency⟯
テキサス州では雨が⟮c+;少ない⟯です。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> 多い/少ない for frequency </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >      There is little rain in Texas.  </div> </div>
Besides たくさん, what is often used to quantify rain? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;多い/少ない⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> in line with the usage of 多い/少ない for amounts </div> </div>
What kind semantic idea&nbsp; must the thing have that 多い / 少ない predicate? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Something quantifiable⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What's the problem here? </div>ムンバイは多い街です。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;ムンバイ is not quantifiable⟯
ムンバイは⟮c+;人口が⟯多い街です。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >        Mumbai is a town with a large population.  </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > since 多い must quantify something quantifiable </div> </div>
Besides using 同じ construction, what is also often used to indicate "the same"? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;同 as a prefix morpheme⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > morphology </div> </div>
What kind of adjective is 同じ?&nbsp; <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;<br>It's a hybrid!⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > but mostly な </div> </div>
What kind of adjectives is 同じ most often like? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;な-adjectives⟯
Onaji as predicate/終止形 (nonpolite present) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;同じだ⟯
Onaji as 終止形 (polite past) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;同じでした⟯
Why is it 同じだ, 同じです etc.? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Because 同じ most often behaves like a な-adjective⟯
How does 同じ connect to nouns? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Without a particle!⟯
What sort of form of 同じ is 同じに? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Adverbial⟯
What sort of form of 同じ is 同じく? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Adverbial⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> reminiscent of the time when 同じ was similar to other adjectives that today are い-adjectives </div> </div>
What does 同じく gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;same as..., ditto⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What form of onaji is 同じくhere, and is that okay? </div>彼と同じく私もイギリス出身です。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;&nbsp;legitimate adverbial of 同じ⟯
The two most common adverbials of 同じ are... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;同じに and 同じく⟯
What does 同じよう (often + に) gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the same way as/similarly/like⟯
ほぼ⟮c+;同じ⟯意味です。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > It has almost the same meaning.  </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> Why is it 同じ here, and not 同じな? </div>僕たちは同じ学校に通っています。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;because 同じ goes before nouns without any modifiers⟯
Why is it weird that な goes between 同じ and の? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;because there is no な when modifying nouns (for 同じ)⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What's missing here? </div>同じのです <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;a な⟯
日本語と同じ⟮c+;です・だ⟯ね。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> な-adj-like conjugation </div> </div>

How do 　新（しん）　字（じ）　体（たい） and simplified chinese characters relate? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Signficant differences, but some are the same⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > In Chinese, many more characters were simplified than in Japanese; some characters were simplified only in the one language, but not in the other; other characters were simplified in the same way in both languages, others in different ways. This means that those who want to learn the writing systems of both Chinese and Japanese must sometimes learn three different variations of one character: traditional Chinese, simplified Chinese, and modern Japanese. </div> </div>

In general in japanese, the ⟮c+;longer⟯ a phrase is, the ⟮c+;politer⟯ it is.
田中さんは先生では⟮c+;polite (丁寧語)::ありませんでした・なかったです⟯。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Mr. Tanaka was not a teacher. </div> </div>
それはコーヒーでは⟮c+;polite (丁寧語)::ありませんでした・なかったです⟯。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > That wasn’t coffee. </div> </div>
小田さんは住民では⟮c+;polite (丁寧語)::ありませんでした・なかったです⟯。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Mr. Oda was not a resident. </div> </div>
な-adjectives are also often called&nbsp; ___ ___ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;adjectival nouns⟯
⟮c+;　主格（しゅかく）⟯|⟮c+;nominative case⟯
<div class='c2-f'> Kanji for? </div><div class='c1-f'> Kana for? </div>⟮c+;なぜ⟯|⟮c+;何故⟯
Transforming mediopassive into active sentence.<pre><code data-codetype="text">電気がついた。 ジェイムズ⟮c+;が⟯電気⟮c+;を⟯つけた。</code></pre>
Transforming active into mediopassive sentence.<pre><code data-codetype="text">ジェイムズが電気をつけた。 電気⟮c+;が⟯ついた。</code></pre>
Transforming active into mediopassive sentence.<pre><code data-codetype="text">雄太がビールを冷やした。 ビール⟮c+;が⟯冷えた。</code></pre>
Transforming active into mediopassive sentence.<pre><code data-codetype="text">ビールが冷えた。 雄太⟮c+;が⟯ビール⟮c+;を⟯冷やした。</code></pre>
机⟮c+;が⟯売れる。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> Intrans verb -&gt; が </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > The desk sells well. </div> </div>
机⟮c+;を⟯売る。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> 自動詞 verb -&gt; を </div><div class="sub all-b"> In the case of が, the desk would do the selling. </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > To sell a desk. </div> </div>
What kind of feeling does を bring with it? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;A feeling of volition⟯
When を is used as a transition marker, what sort of verbs is it used with? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;both transitive and intransitive verbs⟯
When を is used as a transition marker, what case does it (not) mark? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;It doesn't necessarily mark the accusative for these uses⟯
The use of を for motion through a place can more generally stated as を being... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;a transition marker⟯
When を is acting as a transition marker, what semantic field do the verbs have to have? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Related to motion⟯
What does 沸かす take as an object when it means 'to boil water'? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;お湯⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> not 水 </div> </div>
When used as a transition marker, how might be を translated? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Along, through, across⟯
When used as a transition marker, besides space and degree, what can を transition through? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;time⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>日本橋を渡りました。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Someone crossed the Nihonbashi Bridge.⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>ミシシッピ川を泳ぎました。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;I swam across/along/through the Mississippi River. ⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>空を飛びました。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;I flew through/across the sky. ⟯
彼は下り坂⟮c+;を⟯走った<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > He ran downhill.  </div> </div>
公園⟮c+;を⟯走りました。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> transition marker </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I ran through the park.  </div> </div>
アユは川⟮c+;を⟯下った。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> transition marker </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > The sweetfish descended the river.  </div> </div>
⟮c+;　下（くだ）り　坂（ざか）⟯|⟮c+;downhill⟯
⟮c+;　上（のぼ）り　坂（ざか）⟯|⟮c+;uphill⟯
What is sometimes used to help を create the meaning of 'torward' for the direction of action grammar? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;の　方（ほう）⟯
When using の　方（ほう）を, what interpretation of を does it make more likely? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;を as torward (direction of action)⟯
With what kind of verbs can を as direction of action be used? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;both transitive and intransitive⟯
Uses of を include ⟮c+;direct object (acc) marker⟯, ⟮c+;transition marker⟯, ⟮c+;direction of action⟯, ⟮c+;origin of action⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What is を doing here? </div>角を曲がった。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Acting the marker of direction of action⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I turned the corner. </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > arguably this could also be transition marking </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What is を doing here? </div> 岐阜のほうを眺めました。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Acting the marker of direction of action⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > Which is just a specialization of marking the direct object </div> </div>
翔平は先生のほう⟮c+;を⟯向いた。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Shohei faced the teacher.  </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > marker of direction of action </div> </div>
Due to the varied uses of を, what can theoretically happen? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;There could be two or more を in a single sentence⟯
Why are there rarely actually two or more を in a single sentence? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Because one of the を will be left out⟯
Why will a を often be left out if there are two or more? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;because it's generally discouraged to double case particles⟯
If a を or other case particle was left out, how does the grammar act? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;as if it was still there⟯
When indicating the origin of departure, which particle is を often though not always interchangeable with? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;から⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What is を doing here? </div>電車を降りました。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Acting as a origin of departure marker⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What is を doing here? </div>家を出ました <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Acting as a origin of departure marker⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What is を doing here? </div>妻は７時にうちを出ました。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Acting as a origin of departure marker⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > not just acc marker, because 出る is intransitive </div> </div>
What can を as the departure marker do, that から can't? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Be used for leaving for non-physical locations⟯
 去年大学⟮c+;を⟯卒業しました。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> not から </div><div class="sub all-b"> を as origin marker </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I graduated (from) college last year.  </div> </div>
What particle does 超える nearly always use to indicate what's being exceeced? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;を⟯
⟮c+;　上回（うわまわ）る⟯|⟮c+;exceed を⟯
⟮c+;　下回（したまわ）る⟯|⟮c+;to fall below を⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is it を here? </div>竣工から10年を経た建物 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;を as transition marker (time)⟯
Ru verbs are called what in japanese? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;　一段（いちだん）(　動詞（どうし）)⟯
　一段（いちだん）(　動詞（どうし）) are the verbs I usually call what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;る verbs⟯
How often can a ます form modify nouns? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Almost never⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What's the problem here? </div>よく借ります教科書 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Masu form modifying nouns⟯
What conjugations can be placed before NPs to modify them? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;almost all non-polite ones⟯

How can you create negative forms of verbs, besides the ません＆ませんでした versions? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;ない・なかった＋です⟯
U verbs are called what in japanese? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;　五段（ごだん）(　動詞（どうし）)⟯
　一段（いちだん）(　動詞（どうし）) are the verbs I usually call what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;る verbs⟯
⟮c+;アニソン⟯|⟮c+;Anime song⟯
<div class='c1-f'> ます-form </div>待つ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;待ちます⟯
<div class='c1-f'> ます-form </div>死ぬ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;死にます⟯
<div class='c1-f'> ます-form </div>呼ぶ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;呼びます⟯
<div class='c1-f'> ます-form </div>会う <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;会います⟯
<div class='c1-f'> past simple </div>巻く <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;巻いた⟯
<div class='c1-f'> past simple </div>叫ぶ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;叫んだ⟯
<div class='c1-f'> how is this sometimes read, besides いう? </div>言う <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;ゆう⟯
When 言う is read ゆう, what is the past tense? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;ゆった⟯
Where does ゆった come from, most of the time? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Past tense of いう read as ゆう⟯
Why is 言う sometimes read as ゆう? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Because ゆう is easier to say⟯
Casual polite negative of する <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;しないです ⟯
+cas-pol +neg +past する <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;しなかったです⟯
⟮c+;　外（はず）す⟯|⟮c+;unfasten, remove, leave, evade, avoid, remove を⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>レンタルも5000円します。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Rentals also cost 5,000 yen.⟯
When in combination with (esp. list) price, what does する mean? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;To cost⟯
What very common verb means to cost when in context of transactions, esp. the list price? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;する⟯
⟮c+;　掛（か）かる:: starts w k sound ⟯|⟮c+;take time or money⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > context of losing sth. </div> </div>
<div class='c2-f'> For what things/parts of body is this used? </div><div class='c1-f'> What is the verb for this? </div>⟮c+;脱ぐ⟯|⟮c+;taking off anything but accessories⟯
<div class='c2-f'> For what things/parts of body is this used? </div><div class='c1-f'> What is the verb for this? </div>⟮c+;取る:: 1 kanji made up of 1 kana + 1 kana ⟯|⟮c+;removing accessories/headwear⟯<div class="sub">  </div>
<div class='c2-f'> For what things/parts of body is this used? </div><div class='c1-f'> What is the verb for this? </div>⟮c+;外す:: 1 kanji of 2 kana + 1 kana ⟯|⟮c+;removing accessories, headwear, buttons⟯<div class="sub">  </div>
<div class='c2-f'> For what things/parts of body is this used? </div><div class='c1-f'> What is the verb for this? </div>⟮c+;　着（き）る⟯|⟮c+;wearing on upper body or whole body⟯
<div class='c2-f'> For what things/parts of body is this used? </div><div class='c1-f'> What is the verb for this? </div>⟮c+;　履（は）く⟯|⟮c+;wearing on feet, sometimes lower body also⟯
<div class='c2-f'> For what things/parts of body is this used? </div><div class='c1-f'> What is the verb for this? </div>⟮c+;　穿（は）く:: weird kanji one ⟯|⟮c+;Wearing lower body clothing⟯ </div>
<div class='c2-f'> For what things/parts of body is this used? </div><div class='c1-f'> What is the verb for this? </div>⟮c+;　嵌（は）める⟯|⟮c+;Wearing things on your hands/fingers　を (perhaps sometimesl also neckties)⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> derived from more general meaning of to insert; to put in (such that there is a snug fit); to button; to put on (something that envelops, e.g. gloves, ring)​ </div><div class="sub all-b"> if something fits snug, you will not experience a lack of pleasure, but instead a mountain of sweetness&nbsp;¬.¬ </div> </div>
<div class='c2-f'> For what things/parts of body is this used? </div><div class='c1-f'> What is the verb for this? </div>⟮c+;付ける⟯|⟮c+;wearing general accessories, and armor sometimes⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > also する sometimes </div> </div>
<div class='c2-f'> For what things/parts of body is this used? </div><div class='c1-f'> What is the verb for this? </div>⟮c+;　掛（か）ける⟯|⟮c+;putting on/wearing glasses⟯
<div class='c2-f'> For what things/parts of body is this used? </div><div class='c1-f'> What is the verb for this? </div>⟮c+;する:: starts s ⟯|⟮c+;wearing accessories⟯<div class="sub">  </div>

To sense/feel/feel that sthSomething⟮c+;が⟯⟮c+;する⟯

What verb is used for playing games/sports? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;する/やる⟯
⟮c+;アメフト⟯|⟮c+;american football (short)⟯
⟮c+;バスケ⟯|⟮c+;basketball (short)⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is the verb used here する? </div>アメフトをします <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;because する (or やる) is used for playing sports⟯
パチンコを⟮c+;しましょう・しよう⟯よ<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> する/やる is used for playing sports and the like </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Let's play pachinko. </div> </div>
⟮c+;　生（い）け　花（ばな）⟯|⟮c+;flower arrangement⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> lit. making flowers come alive </div><div class="sub all-b"> The tradition dates back to Heian period, when floral offerings were made at altars. Later, flower arrangements were instead used to adorn the tokonoma (alcove) of a traditional Japanese home.  Ikebana reached its first zenith in the 16th century under the influence of Buddhist tea masters and has grown over the centuries, with numerous distinct schools extant today.  Ikebana is counted as one of the three classical Japanese arts of refinement, along with kōdō for incense appreciation and chadō for tea and the tea ceremony. </div> </div>
⟮c+;　華・花（か）　道（どう）:: 2 kanji ⟯|⟮c+;flower arrangement⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> lit way of the flowers </div> </div>

How do we indicate a question, besides by adding some particle or other part of speech? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;rising intonation⟯
What does adding だ to a question word such as 何, 誰, etc. do? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Increase its forcefulness as a question⟯
How can you increase the forcefulness of a question word (often used at the end of a sentence)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;add だ⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> even stronger: だよ </div> </div>

鍵はどこ⟮c+;だ⟯？<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > forceful </div> </div>

When used as a question, what does neg (polite or not) + か sound like, in comparison to the same construct with の・ん? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;rougher, more presumptive⟯
When used as a question, what does neg (polite or not) + の・ん&nbsp;+ か sound like, in comparison to the same construct without&nbsp;の・ん? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;less presumptive, softer⟯

When used as a solicitation, what does neg (polite or not) + か sound like? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Like a solicitation (let's)⟯
What does pos/neg + の? sound like? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;A soft-ish question⟯
As somewhat of an exception to the rules, what is one expecting when one asks 'ないのか'? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;a negative answer⟯
As somewhat of an exception to the rules, how does 'ないのか' sound? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;very rough⟯
In what situation might one use 'ないのか'? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;when feelings are flaring⟯
Where does じゃん originally come from (and sometimes still act as a short version of)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;as a short version of じゃないか⟯

Weirdly, what can one add e.g. to <b>ん</b>じゃない? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;の⟯
<div class='c1-f'> <br><br> </div>How does ないの sound? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Relatively soft⟯
<div class='c1-f'> <br><br> </div>How does ないのか sound? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Very harsh⟯

What is the thing you want marked with for 欲しい? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;が⟯

What main function does は have, besides being the topic marker? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;It acts as the contrast marker⟯
What might the topic marker function of は be subsumed under (according to some theories)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;The contrast marker⟯
Since は often (perhaps actually always) acts as the contrast marker, what can happen in a given sentence, as regards the frequency of は ocurrence? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;There may be multiple は in any given sentence⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What might は be contrasting against here? </div>今日は行きます。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;All other points one could go⟯

<div class='c1-f'> What might は be contrasting against here? </div>本当は嬉しいです。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Not actually being honest⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What is the は in the second sentence implying as an answer? </div>「日本料理は好きですか」「タイ料理は好きです」   <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;that one doesnt like japanese cousine⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Is this legal, and why? </div>私は昨日は昼食は取らなかったんです。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;は as contrast marker⟯
Since は expresses contrast, what might one consider the opposite of は? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;も, which expresses inclusion⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > But this is by no means perfect </div> </div>

⟮c+;「今晩は」in some of Western Japan⟯|⟮c+;晩じまして⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> https://detail.chiebukuro.yahoo.co.jp/qa/question_detail/q1183751576 </div> </div>

<div class="cloze-group-children hide-if-inactive-children"><p>If <code>an <span class="c3-cloze">object belongs to someone</span> who <span class="c4-cloze">you are 尊敬語</span></code> or <span class="c5-cloze"><code>you are using 美化語</code>,</span>&nbsp;you <span class="c2-cloze">add 御 as a prefix</span>.</p> <p>in <span class="c6-cloze">some words</span>, <span class="c7-cloze">御</span> has become  <span class="c1-cloze">lexicalized (and thus unremovable)</span>.</p> <p>In situations where <span class="c8-cloze">other words would</span> get 御 prefixed, <span class="c9-cloze">外来語 only sometimes do</span>. </p> <div>the <span class="c10-cloze">御 prefix</span> can be read:   <table>   <thead>     <tr>       <th>Reading</th>       <th>Context</th>       <th>Conditions</th>     </tr>   </thead>   <tbody class="cloze-group-children hide-if-inactive-children">     <tr>       <td><span class="c11-cloze">お</span></td>       <td><span class="c12-cloze">in front of 和語 (native japanese words)</span></td>       <td><span class="group-before-hide">(generally) <span class="c19-cloze">not used</span> if <span class="c20-cloze">the words starts with お</span>, or <span class="c21-cloze">if it is long</span></span></td>     </tr>     <tr>       <td><span class="c13-cloze">おん</span></td>       <td><span class="c14-cloze">in front of 和語 (native japanese words)</span></td>       <td>if <span class="c22-cloze">the word is more honorific than w/　お</span> (generally <span class="c23-cloze">rare</span>)</td>     </tr>         <tr>       <td><span class="c15-cloze">ご</span></td>       <td><span class="c16-cloze">in front of 漢語 (sino-japanese words)</span></td>     </tr>         <tr>       <td><span class="c17-cloze">み</span></td>       <td><span class="c18-cloze">Religious/grand importance (I think only in front of 和語, but not sure)</span></td>        <td><span class="group-before-hide"><span class="c24-cloze">more fancy versions</span> include <span class="c25-cloze">おみ</span> and <span class="c26-cloze">おんみ</span></span></td>     </tr>   </tbody> </table></div> </div> <span class="cloze-dump">⟮c1;⟯⟮c2;⟯⟮c3;⟯⟮c4;⟯⟮c5;⟯⟮c6;⟯⟮c7;⟯⟮c8;⟯⟮c9;⟯{{c10::}}{{c11::}}{{c12::}}{{c13::}}{{c14::}}{{c15::}}{{c16::}}{{c17::}}{{c18::}}{{c19::}}{{c20::}}{{c21::}}{{c22::}}{{c23::}}{{c24::}}{{c25::}}{{c26::}}</span>

Most 和製漢語 refer to what kind of concepts? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Concepts pertaining to the modern era / imported from the west⟯

⟮c+;　腹（はら）⟯|⟮c+;belly (casual)⟯

Ide (1982) argues that the things people are tracking <b>about other people</b> for determining appropriateness of levels of politeness / honorific usage are as follows:<br>⟮c+;Higher social position⟯<br>⟮c+;Power⟯<br>⟮c+;Debt/obligation⟯<br>⟮c+;Age/seniority⟯

In japan generally, using name without any honorifics is reserved to ⟮c+;very close people⟯ or ⟮c+;people above that person in seniority⟯
Sometimes, if a person who is lower in status uses very polite/honorific speech, what will the other person do? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;reciprocate⟯
In general, besides what person the other person is, what influences the use of formality/politeness? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the formality/politeness of the general situation⟯

Ide (1982) argues that women using more polite/honorific speech is an indication of them having what kind of status? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;lower status⟯
Ide (1982) argues that women using more polite/honorific speech is an indication of them having lower status why? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;because generally lower status people have to use more honorific speech in japanese⟯

女言葉・女性語 containing more 敬語 etc. indicates&nbsp; (following Ide) a lower status either because women ⟮c+;qua women are lower status⟯, or women ⟮c+;hold roles which generally have lower status⟯
in much popular modern discourse, how is 女性語 said to be connected with the womanhood of the japanese woman? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;naturally (japanese women speak 女性語 qua womanhood)⟯

⟮c+;　鶏冠（とさか）⟯|⟮c+;cockscomb⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > almost always in kana </div> </div>

How often does Lyman's law (there can be no more than one voiced obstruent (a consonant sound formed by obstructing airflow) within a morpheme.) hold?` <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;often but not always⟯
Why does ん not block Lyman's law? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;because nasals are not obstruents⟯

⟮c+;　伝統（でんとう）⟯|⟮c+;tradition, custom⟯
⟮c+;(日本の)　伝統芸能（でんとうげいのう）⟯|⟮c+;Japanese traditional performing arts&nbsp; is a general term for the arts and skills that have existed in Japan since ancient times. It refers to the tangible and intangible arts and crafts that have been passed down or discontinued in a particular form, either as an incidental part of the culture, entertainment, rituals, or festivals of a particular class or mass of people, or as a systematic part of an event. It includes poetry, music, dance, painting, crafts, and geido.&nbsp;⟯

Besides indicating the ⟮c+;progressive⟯ aspect, ている can also indicate the ⟮c+;habitual⟯ and the ⟮c+;stative⟯ aspect
ている・てある are fundamentally concerned with what linguistic feature? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;aspect⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What aspect is ている indicating here? </div>教師をしています <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;stative⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What aspect is ている indicating here? </div>A学校に行っています。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;habitual⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > not stative, as you are not always going to school </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What aspect is ている indicating here? </div> 古着を着ています。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;stative⟯
For motion verbs, what aspect does ている always indicate, if not habitual? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;stative⟯
For motion verbs, what kind of stative is the stative that ている indicates? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the one after the motion has been completed⟯
For motion verbs, the state after the motion has been completed is indicated how? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;ている⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div> 彼はもう帰っている <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;He's already gone home.⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > ている + motion verb stative </div> </div>
how do you combine the aspectual functions of ている with the 'without' meaning of ないで? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;ないでいる⟯
ないでいる is a combination of which two forms? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;ないで＝Without,　ている = aspectual functions⟯
how do you express without -ing (or without + stative/habitual)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;ないでいる⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > contains a d sound </div> </div>
How is the ず form used, grammatically (in relation to the sentence)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;as an AdvP⟯
One kana AdvP -making without form? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Xず⟯
A more formal variant of ず is? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;ずに⟯
ずに relates how to ず? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;more formal (according to imabi)⟯
how do we merge ている and ず(に)？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;ず（に）いる⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > yes, this is correct, the て form is dropped, cf. https://www.imabi.net/teiru.htm </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> Read how? </div>NG <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;エヌジー⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Means what? </div>NG <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;no good; not allowed; not acceptable, outtake⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Gloss? </div>決して病気にならないでいることは不可能だ。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;      It is impossible to never get sick.   ⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > without-form + ている aspectual (here stative) </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > literally: certainly sick become without STAT NOM TOP impossible COP </div> </div>
In some dialects, what is used instead of ている？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;ておる (yes, even in non-formal speech)⟯
In some dialects,&nbsp;<span style="background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">ておる is used instead of</span>&nbsp;ている even in which situations？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;even in normal (non-formal) situations⟯
The dialectal とる、ちょる for ている are derived from which form? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;ておる (as a replacement for ている)⟯
Dialectal forms of て(い)る are ⟮c+;とる⟯、⟮c+;ちょろ⟯
てある indicates what aspect (only)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;stative⟯
te + what indicates stative (always)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;てある⟯
What specific, common verb cannot use てある？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;来る⟯
The state resulting from てある has to be what, now? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;currently true⟯
Who must have caused the てある state? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;&nbsp;a voluntary actor⟯
How was the てある state caused (related to the agent that caused it)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;purposefully⟯
What class of verbs can the てある state <b>only</b>&nbsp;be used with? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;transitive verbs⟯
&nbsp;てある can&nbsp;<b>only</b>&nbsp;be used with transitive verbs, but what is up with the particles? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;を cannot be used⟯
窓が⟮c+;開け⟯てあります。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b">てある needs transitive verbs</div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b">  The window is open (and this was caused by someone). </div> </div>
アンケートは集めて⟮c+;ある⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >     The questionnaires have been gathered. (and are now gathered, by a human) </div> </div>
ストーブ⟮c+;が⟯つけ<b>てあります。</b><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > The heater was turned on (by someone) and has been kept that way. </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What must be true about how the tree ended up on the ground? </div>木が倒してある。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;by voluntary action⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What must be true about the tree and the ground? </div>木が倒してある。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;it must still be there⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why the dinner&nbsp; marked with が？ </div>晩ご飯が作ってある。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;because てある doesn't accept を, and thus always uses が⟯
The functioning of てある is kind of similar to which form/voice? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;passive form voice⟯
⟮c+;ユーラシア⟯|⟮c+;eurasia⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> rarely also ユーラジア </div> </div>
⟮c+;　国名（こくめい）⟯|⟮c+;name of a country⟯

⟮c+;アジア⟯|⟮c+;Asia⟯

What happens sometimes, although rarely, when listing with と？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;there also is a と after the last item⟯
Having a と after the last item in a と list is how common/allowed? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;uncommon but fine⟯
と as 'and' can be only used with what words/phrases? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;nouns/NPs⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is this で and not と, given it seems to be connecting two nouns? </div>私は日本人で医者です。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;because it actually isn't, it's connecting two predicate phrases, since it really is short for "I am japanese and I am a doctor"⟯
これ⟮c+;と⟯それは同じです。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >     This and that are the same.   </div> </div>
What could be here?<br>日本語のクラスにはアメリカ人と、イギリス人と、カナダ人⟮c+;と/Ø⟯がいます。<br><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b">     There are Americans, English, and Canadians in (my) Japanese class.  </div> </div>
と can mean what, e.g. 彼氏と一緒に宿題をした。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;with⟯
父と母⟮c+;と⟯公園に行きます。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > 　　　 I'm going to the park with my father and mother.  </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> what does the と gloss as here? </div>友達と散歩に出かけた。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;with⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
⟮c+;　共（とも）に:: starts t ⟯|⟮c+;together; with​⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> often collocation with と (as Xと共に) </div><div class="sub all-b"> similar to 一緒に </div><div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
共に and 一緒に often take what to specify with whom they are doing the action? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;と⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
⟮c+;x　共（とも）:: 1 kanji of 2 kana ⟯|⟮c+;both, all (suffix, can be added to other words)⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> e.g. 二人共 </div><div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div> 彼女と時々けんかする。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;      I sometimes argue with her. ⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
車⟮c+;と⟯ぶつかった。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I collided with a car. </div> </div>
If something is being compared, what is one of the comparands often marked with? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;と⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
What does と used for comparison sometimes gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;as⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> trans? </div> 彼と同じ考えです。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;      That is the same idea as his. <br><br>⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What is the と here doing? </div>その子はお父さんと似ている。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;comparing ('as')⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
Besides と, how is the thing being compared with 似ている also often marked? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;に⟯
⟮c+;みぞれ⟯|⟮c+;sleet⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
⟮c+;　小雨（こさめ, more rarely しょうう）⟯|⟮c+;light rain, drizzle⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
⟮c+;　大（おお）　雨（あめ）⟯|⟮c+;downpour, heavy rain⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
in contrast to になる, となる indicate a change that is what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;discrete (in one thing)⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
A sudden change to something uses what particle? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;と<br>⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
と cannot be used for what changes? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;changes from a continuous process⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
と for change often sounds what, as regards tone/formality? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;stiff/formal⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> Why is it 'と' here? </div>いよいよ運動会の日となりました。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;sudden/discrete change⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
小雨⟮c+;となった⟯。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp;It became a drizzle (suddenly). </div> </div>
Why do many intransitive verbs end in -aru? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;because they evolved from old japanese verbs via the 未然形&nbsp;⟯
if they evolved from old japanese verbs via the 未然形 (and many did) <b>intransitive</b> verbs... <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c+;end -aru⟯
because they evolved from old japanese verbs via the izenkei(no longer exists), many transitive verbs... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;end -eru⟯
&nbsp;many transitive verbs end -eru because? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;because they evolved from old japanese verbs via the izenkei(已然形, no longer exists),⟯
 みぞれが雪⟮c+;と⟯なりました。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >       The sleet turned to snow. (all of a sudden) </div> </div>
⟮c+;　多勢（たぜい）⟯|⟮c+;great numbers, numerical superiority⟯
⟮c+;　無勢（ぶ/むぜい）⟯|⟮c+;numerical inferiority; being outnumbered⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is it に? </div>　多勢（たぜい）に　無勢（ぶぜい） <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;に for deep connection&nbsp;⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this pattern gloss as? </div>AをBにする <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;to make/have A be a B way (into a B)⟯
to make/have A be a B way: ⟮c+;Aを⟯⟮c+;B(に/と)⟯⟮c+;する⟯
for the to make/have A be a B way pattern, what can you use, instead of に? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;と⟯
for the to make/have A be a B way pattern, using と instead of に emphasizes what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the substance of the result⟯
⟮c+;いよいよ:: starts i ⟯|⟮c+;more and more; increasingly, finally, indeed⟯<div class="sub">  </div>
殺害事件⟮c+;を⟯小説⟮c+;に⟯する。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >     To make the murder case into a novel.  </div> </div>
What can adverbial+する&nbsp; mean? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;just to make something something, like you'd expect⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > にする can also mean to choose, but that's not what I mean </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>彼は彼女を幸せにした。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;     He made her happy. ⟯
the pattern AをBにする is actually what, if B is a 形容詞? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;AをB(adverbial)する⟯
the pattern AをBに/adverbialする also works in what reduced state? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;leaving out the Aを⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>ボリュームを高くする。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;to turn up the volume⟯
In general, with what is the に to tell time not used? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;time words such as 去年, 今日、明日 etc.⟯
学校は毎朝８時１５分⟮c+;に⟯始まります。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > not nothing </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > 　　　School begins every morning at 8:15.  </div> </div>
に can also sometimes do what, when placed between two things (probably NPs)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;act as 'and' (similar to と)⟯
When acting as and, what nuance does に carry (according to IMABI)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;of a deep connection⟯
Instead of と 'and' especially to indicate a deep connection, what is sometimes also used? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;に⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 1 kana </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> Why is に being used here? </div>新郎に新婦 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;に for and with deep connection⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>待ちに待った <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;waited and waited, long/eagerly awaited⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>赤ちゃんは泣きに泣いた。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;The baby cried and cried⟯
the stem に verb pattern (e.g. 待ちに待つ) has what tone? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;somewhat literary⟯ Very / strongly verbing: ⟮c+;Verb stem⟯ + ⟮c+;に⟯ + ⟮c+;same verb⟯ Verb stem + に + same verb creates what meaning? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;that the verb is being done to a large/strong extent⟯
（こ・そ・あ）ちら can be used as a politer version of what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;（こ・そ・あ）れ⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > contains an e-sound </div> </div>
（こ・そ・あ）ちら can relate how to （こ・そ・あ）れ? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;politer version⟯
Politer version of こ・そ・あ）れ is? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;（こ・そ・あ）ちら⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is it こちら here? </div>こちらは新製品でございます。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;politer version of これ⟯
⟮c+;polite::そちら⟯はお買い得ですよ<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > That is a good bargain.  </div> </div>
（こ・そ・あ）ちら can be used as a politer version of what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;（こ・そ・あそ）こ⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > contains an o-sound </div> </div>
（こ・そ・あ）ちら can relate how to （こ・そ・あ）こ? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;politer version⟯
Politer version of こ・そ・あ　れ is? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;（こ・そ・あ）ちら⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is it こちら here? </div>こちらは昨日、酷い雨でした。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;more polite version of ここ⟯
⟮c+;　親子丼（おやこどん）⟯|⟮c+;oyakodon; chicken and egg on rice​; threesome including a mother and her daughter⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> The food meaning is far more common, the sexual one far more interesting :P </div> </div>
こちら can be used as an indirect way to refer to whom? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;oneself (first person)⟯
こちら can be a personal pronoun for which two grammatical persons? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;first person and third person⟯
こちら can be used to refer to oneself (1st person) with what feeling? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;indirectly⟯
When こちら　is used to refer to other people (3rd person), what people is it used for? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;people of equal/higher status⟯
When（こ・そ・あ）ちら is used to refer to other people 　that have especially high status, what should be added? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;様⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Which function is&nbsp; こちら assuming here? </div> こちらこそ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Indirect 1p reference⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Which function is&nbsp; こちら assuming here? </div>こちらはいつでも結構です。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Indirect 1p reference⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Which function is&nbsp; こちら assuming here? </div>こちらはジョーンズ夫人です。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;3p polite reference⟯
こちら⟮c+;様⟯にお水を差し上げてください。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Very high status </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> Why is it そちら here? </div>そちらはもう寒くなりましたか。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;more polite version of そこ⟯
そちら can be a personal pronoun for which grammatical person? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;second person⟯
そちら is used to refer to others (2nd person) with what formality/status? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;polite/formal⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Which function is&nbsp; そちら assuming here? </div>そちらのご意見を聞かせてください。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;2p polite reference⟯
The っち contractions of こそあ ちら have what kind of formality? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;they are casual⟯
あちら can be a personal pronoun for which grammatical person? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;third person⟯
あちら is used to refer to others (3rd person) with what formality/status? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;formal, polite⟯
あちら is used to refer to others (3rd person) formally/politely, but is different from こちら how? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;あちら is distal⟯
<div class='c1-f'> In japanese? </div>That's my line <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;それはこっちのセリフだ⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > or variants </div> </div>
