こちら、そちら etc are abbreviated how? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;こっち、そっち etc⟯
 そちら⟮c+;様⟯のお  電話番号をいただけますか。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > much status above wow </div> </div>
⟮c+;　疑問詞（ぎもんし）⟯|⟮c+;interrogative (word)⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> like なぜ、どこ、なになど </div> </div>
Where (as relates to medium) is の reduced to ん？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;in spoken speech⟯
In general, where can question words appear in the sentence in japanese (provided the sentence supports it)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;pretty much anywhere⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > Isn't this probably only true for adverb-like question words, </div> </div>
Generally, what construct do&nbsp;question words colligate with? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;(explanatory) の・ん...⟯
Seemingly using a conceptual metaphor of space, what can you sometimes use instead of なに？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;どこ⟯
日本の⟮c+;どこ⟯が好きですか。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > starts d </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > What about japan do you like? </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> used like which word class？ </div>いつ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;adverb⟯
<div class='c1-f'> used like which word class？ </div>なぜ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;adverb⟯
<div class='c1-f'> used like which word class？ </div>なに、どこ、だれ。。。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;nouns⟯
⟮c+;Xいつになる⟯|⟮c+;When will X happen? / when x will happen⟯
⟮c+;　揉（も）み　揉（も）み:: contains reduplication ⟯|⟮c+;massage, squeezing⟯<div class="sub">  </div>
⟮c+;　揉（も）む⟯|⟮c+;to knead, to rub, to crumple を⟯
⟮c+;　揉（も）める⟯|⟮c+;to disagree; to dispute; bicker, worry, fret が⟯
⟮c+;　声優（せいゆう）⟯|⟮c+;voice actor or actress (radio, animation, etc.)⟯
(っ)つ(う)か、(っ)てか are short versions of what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;というか⟯
Very casual version of というか, besides (っ)つ(う)か? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;(っ)てか ⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > also quite short </div> </div>
Very casual version of というか, besides (っ)てか? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;(っ)つ(う)か⟯
てゆうか is a version of what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;というか⟯
⟮c+;　独立（どくりつ）:: d... ⟯|⟮c+;independence, separation, independent authority that is free from interference⟯<div class="sub">  </div>
⟮c+;　従属（じゅうぞく）⟯|⟮c+;subordination, dependence⟯
⟮c+;　節（せつ）⟯|⟮c+;clause⟯<div class="sub"> <div class='sub f'> linguistics terminology </div> </div>
⟮c+;　主節（しゅせつ）⟯|⟮c+;main clause⟯
⟮c+;　従(属)節（じゅう(ぞく)せつ）⟯|⟮c+;subordinate clause​⟯
⟮c+;　巨大（きょだい）⟯|⟮c+;huge; gigantic; enormous⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What is の doing here? </div>きのう山を登ったのは、健太君でした。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;の as nominalizer⟯
A verb phrase placed in front of a NP to modify it is what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;a relative clause⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > specifically japanese definition </div> </div>
A verb phrase placed in front of what to modify it is a relative clause?a <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;a NP⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > japanese-specific definition </div> </div>
Since 形容詞 contain the copula within themselves, when in front of NPs what might one say they are equivalent to? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;relative clauses⟯
Why might we say 形容詞 are equivalent to relative clauses when in front of NPs? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Since 形容詞 contain the copula within themselves⟯
besides as adjectives (predicative adjectives, etc), 形容詞 are sometimes analyzed as ⟮c+;intransitive⟯ ⟮c+;stative⟯ ⟮c+;verbs⟯.
What does japanese fairly frequently use where english might use an adjective? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;a relative clause⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > (contains more words) </div> </div>
In general, what particle does not appear in a relative question (the ones marked with か)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;は⟯
In general, if は appears in a embedded/relative question, that is a clue that... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;you are not actually in the embedded clause, and if you are, it’s not being used to mark the topic.⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What is どれがおいしいかまずいか here? </div>どれがおいしいかまずいかさっぱりわかりません。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;a relative/embedded question⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>この生物は何か教えてください。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Please tell me what creature this is. ⟯
どの宿題が難しかった⟮c+;か⟯教えてください。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Please tell me which homework was difficult.  </div> </div>
かどうか glosses as what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;whether or not⟯
How do you mark a relative/embedded question? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;with か⟯
What does XかYか gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;(whether) X or Y⟯
whether X or Y is the case is something we might express how in japanese? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;ｘかｙか⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What would adding a どうか to the か change the translation into? </div>お風呂が十分に熱いか確かめてください。= Please check if the bath is hot enough.   <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Please check whether or not the bath is hot enough. ⟯
彼女が虫が嫌い⟮c+;かどうか⟯わかりません。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I don't know whether or not she hates bugs.&nbsp; </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>夫が本当に幸せかどうか分かりません。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;I really don’t know whether or not my husband is really happy. ⟯
If after a relative/embedded question there is a quantifier, what does the quantifier refer to? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the relative/embedded question⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What is the 大体 referring to? </div> 山口さんは誰が歌ったか<b>大体</b>知っているでしょう。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the relative/embedded question in front of it⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > since 大体 is a quantifier </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What is the 全部 referring to? </div>私は何が届いたか<b>全部</b>知っています。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the relative/embedded question in front of it⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > since 全部 is a quantifier </div> </div>
In general, like what phrase/word class do embedded/relative questions work? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;like nouns/noun phrases⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does the を here prove? </div>警察は誰が犯行現場にいたかを調べています。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;that rel/emb questions act a lot like like nouns/noun phrases⟯
古いかどうか⟮c+;を⟯調べる方法 <div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Method of investigating whether or not it’s old  </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > not necessary, but possible </div> </div>
爆発するか⟮c+;が⟯知りたいです。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I want to know if it will explode. </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > not necessary but possible </div> </div>
In general, in embedded/relative questions, what can you put before the か? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;similar particles as in actual questions⟯
By extension from 'somehow or other', what does どうか also mean? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;please⟯
Please <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;どうか⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > starts w d </div> </div>
things like の・ん、だ、の・んだ add what to embedded/relative questions? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;more uncertainty/weight⟯
According to IMABI, in ⟮c+;embedded/relative questions⟯, in order of uncertainty: ⟮c+;ん・のだか⟯＞⟮c+;だか⟯＞⟮c+;ん・のか⟯＞⟮c+;か⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>この辺は何だか静かですね。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;This area is rather/kinda quiet, isn't it?  ⟯
⟮c+; 何だか⟯眠い。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I'm kinda/sorta/somehow sleepy. </div> </div>
...か...か (or derivatives like ...のか...のか) can be used how, besides a whether x or y? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;just as a general list of options⟯
When ...か...か (but not derivatives) are being used to list options, what can happen to the final か？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;it can be left out⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is it か here? </div>水かミルクを飲んでください。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;か pattern for listing options⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is it か here? </div> すしか刺し身を注文してください。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;か pattern for listing options⟯
 すし⟮c+;か⟯刺し身を注文してください。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Order either sushi or sashimi.  </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > 1 kana </div> </div>
公園に行くか、デパートに行く⟮c+;か or nothing⟯ですね。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Either go to the park or go to the department store, right?  </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What is the　んだか pattern being used here for? </div>もう誰が死ぬんだか、みんな死ぬんだかわからない。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;&nbsp;listing options⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is there no final か here? </div>水かミルクを飲んでください。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;'cause it can be left out⟯
In a way, how can the relationship between な (if it's not being used to disambiguate の・ん) and である (or similar copula) be seen?&nbsp; <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;な being a form of である/ the copula⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > not the particle </div> </div>
How might we say <q>from x to y</q>? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;XからYまで⟯
What might から gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;from⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > when as a 'postposition' </div> </div>
<div class='c2-f'> If we said this marked a case, which case would that be? </div><div class='c1-f'> If we said this was marked by a particle, which particle would that be? </div>⟮c+;から⟯|⟮c+;Ablative case⟯
<div class='c2-f'> If we said this marked a case, which case would that be? </div><div class='c1-f'> If we said this was marked by a particle, which particle would that be? </div>⟮c+;へ・に⟯|⟮c+;lative case⟯
When recieving, から can be used for what, に for what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;から for anything, に for people only⟯
When recieving, what particle can be used for anything, and what for people only? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;から for anything, に for people only⟯
 When から is used to show the place of transit or departure, it may be replaced by what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;を :: 1 kana⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>子犬から育てたよ。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;　　 I raised it from (since it was) a puppy. ⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>これらのコンピューターは各種５万円からです。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;　　 These computers start at 50,000 yen.<br><br>⟯
What tense can you not use まで with? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;past tense⟯
 僕は9歳⟮c+;まで⟯ローマで育ちました。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >     I was raised in Rome until I was nine.   </div> </div>

What does まで gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;    to/until/till&nbsp;&nbsp;⟯
までに is generally used with what semantic field? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;    time⟯
<div class='c1-f'> generally uses what construction? </div>By the time... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;までに ⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>零時までに三冊読む。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;      To read three books by midnight.  ⟯
 日が出る⟮c+;まで⟯寝る。 <div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >     To sleep until the sun rises. <br><br> </div> </div>

Despite ので being derived from のだ (prob), in general, what can you still use in front of it? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;polite forms (including です)⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > no, you can't use だので </div> </div>
Because ので is prob derived from のだ (prob), what can you not use in front of it, unless you're speaking dialect? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;だ⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What was this before being slurred? </div>んで <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;ので⟯
Because it is weaker, what kind of verb forms can you not use ので with? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;any kind of imperative (or similar)⟯
<div class='c1-f'> How is ので funcitoning here? </div>すまない、もう先約があるんで。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;basically adding explanatory tone just as のだ or similar might⟯
犬⟮c+;な⟯のだ<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >  It's a dog. (explanatory tone) </div> </div>
静か⟮c+;な⟯ので僕がなにか言いたかった<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > It's been quiet, so I wanted to say something. </div> </div>
In general, how correct is だのに? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;dialectal⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>新しいのに <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;even though its new⟯
 犬⟮c+;な⟯のに        <div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Even though he's a dog. </div> </div>
 彼はとても年を取っている⟮c+;のに⟯元気ですよ。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >     Although/even though he's very old, he's healthy!  </div> </div>
食べないの? せっかく作った⟮c+;のに⟯。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 2 kana </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > You're not going to eat it? Even though I went through all the trouble of making it?<br><br> </div> </div>
<div class='c2-f'> What does this generally translate as? </div><div class='c1-f'> How might we say this in japanese? (4 kana) </div>⟮c+;...いいのに⟯|⟮c+;I wish that... (or should...)⟯
いいのに as in "I wish/if only" is often preceded by what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the conditional (たら・ば)⟯
conditional(たら・ば) + いいのに generally implies what about the thing in the conditional? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;that it isn't the case⟯
conditional(たら・ば) + いいのに can be translated as <q>⟮c+;I wish⟯</q>, <q>⟮c+;if only⟯</q>, <q>⟮c+;you should⟯</q>, <q>⟮c+;why don't you⟯</q> (and similar, of course)
In general, if you use のに, the outcome is how, value-/desirability-wise? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;negative (althought not always)⟯
In general, if you use のに without a second clause, what is said to be regrettable? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;reality⟯
The conditional + いいのに pattern is actually just a slight specialization of which pattern? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;conditional + いい⟯
In the conditional + いい pattern, what may the いい be replaced with, esp. if at the end of the sentence? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;なあ・ねえ⟯
What does the conditional + いい generally gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;I wish...,&nbsp; should...⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>すみません、どこで 降りればいいですか。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Excuse me, where should I get off?⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>どのボタンを押せばいいかわからなかった。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;I didn't know which button to push.⟯
besides should or I wish, what does conditional + いい&nbsp; also sometimes gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;may (as in you may take off your shoes)⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Roughly translates as what </div>X癖に (Most often spelled in kana as くせに)</span> <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Even though X⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Is similar to what? </div>X癖に (Most often spelled in kana as くせに) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Xのに⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Is different to のに how? </div>X癖に (Most often spelled in kana as くせに) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;X is implied to be way more negative⟯
男⟮c+;の⟯くせに<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >  Even though you’re a man…  </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss&nbsp; as? </div>女のくせに <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;even though you’re a woman⟯
何だ、自分がミスした⟮c+;くせに⟯･･･<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > What? Even though you yourself have messed up…  </div> </div>
あんた、戦争の経験もない⟮c+;くせに⟯べらべらしゃべてるなんて<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > k... </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > You've never been in a war before, and yet you talk and talk and talk. </div> </div>
<div class='c2-f'> More extreme alternative of? </div><div class='c1-f'> More extreme alternative? </div>⟮c+;くせして  ⟯|⟮c+;くせに⟯
あの山の小さ⟮c+;な/い⟯町に住んでいます。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I live in the small town on that mountain.  </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> Why couldn't it be な here? </div>耳が小さい猫がいるんだ。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;predicative -&gt; 連体詞 impossible⟯
between 小さいと小さな (and 大きい・大きな), which can you use for money? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;-い⟯
between 小さいと小さな (and 大きい・大きな), which can you use for age? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;-い⟯
&nbsp;小さい and 大きい are variants which you can use for which semantic fields, but which you can't use their な cousins for? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;money, age⟯
in the adnominal position おかし⟮c+;い⟯ is generally used for something ⟮c+;funny⟯, and おかし⟮c+;な⟯ is generally used for something ⟮c+;suspicious/weird⟯
in the adnominal position 新⟮c+;たな⟯ is generally used for something ⟮c+;subjective/cool⟯; 新⟮c+;しい⟯ is generally used for something ⟮c+;objective⟯
in the adnominal position&nbsp;&nbsp;柔らか⟮c+;な⟯ is can be used for something ⟮c+;figuratively soft⟯, while 柔らか⟮c+;い⟯ is generally only used for something ⟮c+;that is literally soft⟯
In general, where are compounds using 前 read ぜん mostly used? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;in the written language⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > true for most 音読み compounds </div> </div>
In general, how is 前 mostly used in the spoken language? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;standalone and read まえ⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>食べる前に、手を洗います。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;I wash my hands before I eat. ⟯
彼は3年⟮c+;前に⟯死んだ。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > He died three years ago. </div> </div>
In general, as what part of speech is 　前（まえ） used? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;noun/の-adj⟯
most of the time, what is 前 followed by? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;に⟯
⟮c+;　帰京（ききょう） (often used as a する verb)⟯|⟮c+;returning to (one's home in) Tokyo⟯
⟮c+;　直前（ちょくぜん）⟯|⟮c+;directly in front, directly ahead, just before⟯
車の⟮c+;直前⟯に人が突然飛び出してきた。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 2 kanji </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > A person suddenly jumped out right in front of the car. </div> </div>
爆発直前⟮c+;に⟯ガソリンが気化したような臭いがしていた。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > There was a smell of gasoline vaporizing right before the explosion.  </div> </div>
　後（あと）, has a ⟮c+;spatial sense ('behind')⟯, a ⟮c+;temperoral sense ('after')⟯, a sense of ⟮c+;the remainder⟯, ⟮c+;the aftermath⟯, and something like ⟮c+;'what's more'⟯.
⟮c+;後⟯は任せて。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I'll take care of the rest. </div> </div>
跡 is read as あと when it refers to what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;traces/tracks/marks/signs/remains⟯
&nbsp;あと is written how when it refers to traces/tracks/marks/signs/remains <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;跡⟯
when it refers to traces/tracks/marks/signs/remains, how is 跡 read? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;あと⟯
痕 is read as あと when it refers to what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;a scar⟯
&nbsp;あと is written how when it refers to a scar <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;痕 or 跡⟯
when it refers to a scar, how is 痕 read? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;あと⟯
⟮c+;　傷（きず）　跡/痕（あと）⟯|⟮c+;scar&nbsp;⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-b c1-f" > 2 kanji </div> </div>
後ろAnd後 both can refer to after, but only 後ろ can refer to... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the rear part of something⟯
車の⟮c+;後ろ⟯にくまがいます<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > There's a bear in the back of the car. </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > not 後 because the back part is 後ろ only </div> </div>
⟮c+;クモ⟯|⟮c+;spider⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > kanji are 蜘蛛 </div> </div>
⟮c+;くらげ⟯|⟮c+;jellyfish⟯
if you're using VP + 後, what must the tense be? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;past tense⟯
大変⟮c+;だった⟯後は、良いことがあるのかな<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > copula </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >   　I wonder if there can be anything good after things being so terrible.    </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > must be past tense because of 後 </div> </div>
Besides general sentence function&nbsp; particles, 後 seems to mainly occur with ⟮c+;に⟯・⟮c+;で⟯・⟮c+;から⟯ or alternatively with ⟮c+;no particle⟯
In contrast to あと, which nuance(s) does のち only have? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;only the temporal nuance⟯
What does verbてから gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;after doing...⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>別れてから会っていない <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;　　 I haven't met her since we split up. ⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What is てから indicating here? </div>よく考えてから答えます。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;doing something after doing something else&nbsp;⟯
日本に来⟮c+;てから⟯もう10年になります。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > 　　 It has already been ten years since I came to Japan.  </div> </div>
as readings of 後, when standalone, ⟮c+;のち⟯ and ⟮c+;ご⟯ are used ⟮c+;pretty similarly⟯ (in relation to each other).
お⟮c+;後⟯は何にしますか。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > a... </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > What will you be having next/after?  </div> </div>
僕は、ペルシャ軍の⟮c+;後⟯を追いかけた。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I chased after the Persian army.   </div> </div>
In general, what do we use when we want to indicate the time when something happens? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;　時（とき）⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > e.g. When others are talking, when beginning an examination, when running etc. </div> </div>
The tenses in the structure something時something decide what, besides the event's relation to the present? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the events (temporal) relation to each other⟯
The tenses in the structure something時something decide what, besides the events temporal relation to each other? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the events temporal relation to the present⟯
What governs the tense when the time of the clause before 時 becomes irrelevant for whatever reason? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the final verb⟯
&nbsp;when the time of the clause before 時 becomes irrelevant for whatever reason, what does the final verb do? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;govern the tense fo the clause⟯
According to IMABI, when you use a 時 construction, if ⟮c+;both events⟯ are seen to be ⟮c+;instantaneous⟯ and be happening ⟮c+;at the same time⟯, or when the event is ⟮c+;reoccurring/habitual⟯, the ⟮c+;tense before 時⟯ becomes irrelevant.
If the second clause in clause時clause is ている, it happens when? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;while the first clause is happening⟯
<div class='c1-f'> When are you buying the radio? </div>私は日本に行くとき、ラジオを買います。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;in the future, right when you are going to japan⟯
<div class='c1-f'> When are you buying the radio? </div>私は日本に行くとき、ラジオを買いました <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;in the past, right when you are going to japan⟯
<div class='c1-f'> When are you buying the radio? </div>私は日本に行ったとき日本製のテレビを買う <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;after you will have gone to japan⟯
<div class='c1-f'> When are you buying the radio? </div>私は日本に行ったときテレビを買いました。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;after you will have gone to japan⟯
When using clause1時clause2, the verb in clause 2 (v2) determines what (which v1 does not)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the time in relation to the present⟯
When using clause1時clause2, the time in relation to the present is determined by what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the verb in clause 2⟯
When using clause1時clause2, if c1 is present, and c2 is past, which happend first? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;c2⟯
When using clause1時clause2, if c1 is past, and c2 is present, which happend first? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;c1⟯
⟮c+;　前後（ぜんご）⟯|⟮c+;front and behind, (right) before and after, around, consequences⟯
⟮c+;　前（ぜん）　後（ご）　関（かん）　係（けい）⟯|⟮c+;context (text in which a word appears)⟯
besides すぐ plainly and すぐと how is すぐ sometimes also used as an adverb? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;すぐに⟯
直ぐに is what, related to adverbials of 直ぐ? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;one of three options (the other being 直ぐ itself and 直ぐと)&nbsp;⟯
besides すぐ plainly and すぐに how is すぐ sometimes also used as an adverb? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;すぐと⟯
When in a more habitual/stative sense, what does 直ぐ gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;quick to..., readily...⟯
⟮c+;　抵抗（ていこう）⟯|⟮c+;resistance⟯
⟮c+;　抵触（ていしょく）:: T... ⟯|⟮c+;infringement, violation, collision, logical conflict⟯<div class="sub">  </div>
⟮c+;　抵（てい）　当（とう）:: starts te ⟯|⟮c+;mortgage, security, pledge⟯<div class="sub">  </div>
⟮c+;　最（も）　早（はや）⟯|⟮c+;now; already; (with negative verbs) no longer⟯
⟮c+;　度々（たびたび）:: reduplication, starts t ⟯|⟮c+;often, frequently, repeatedly⟯<div class="sub">  </div>
⟮c+;　度（たび）:: t... ⟯|⟮c+;time, times (x5 for example)⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > beware the reading </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> Glosses as what? </div>x　置（お）きに <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+; x apart, every ... with x between (e.g. put sth with 5 m apart, do something with 5 days in between)⟯
<div class='c2-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><div class='c1-f'> What might this gloss as? </div>⟮c+;１日おきに/２日ごとに⟯|⟮c+;every other day⟯
things like 毎whatever trigger what meaning for ていた? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;habitual meaning⟯
In general, ものだ(or other forms, e.g. である) either expresses ⟮c+;a strong opinion that something just is/should be a way⟯, or ⟮c+;expresses strong emotion⟯
When ものだ(or other forms, e.g. である)  expresses a strong opinion, that is often either that something ⟮c+;is a fact⟯ or something ⟮c+;should be a certain way (based on custom, common sense, etc.)⟯
When ものだ(or other forms, e.g. である)  is preceded by the past tense, it generally implies what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;reminiscence / recollection⟯
When ものだ(or other forms, e.g. である)  implies reminiscence, what comes in front of it? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;past tense⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What is ものだ doing here? </div>留学したいものだ。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;expressing strong emotion⟯
Transitivity and intransitivity in japanese are generally realized how? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;in different verb pairs⟯
Verb pairs (e.g. 落ちろ、落とす) differ in what respect? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;transitivity⟯
<div class='c2-f'> What are these? </div><div class='c1-f'> How do these look? </div>⟮c+;「」⟯|⟮c+;japanese quote marks⟯
⟮c+;　正義（せいぎ）の　味方（みかた）⟯|⟮c+;champion of justice&nbsp;⟯
と might be said to be like what  written thing, but spoken(related to quotes)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;spoken quote makrs⟯
If you're directly quoting what someone said, what forms can the verb in the quote be in? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;any form⟯
彼女は「雨が降りません」と⟮c+;言いました⟯(polite)。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >     She said, "It won't rain."   </div> </div>
Annoyingly, what may happen to the verb after the と when used for citation? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;it may be left out⟯
When we're citing thoughts, what form can the verb in the thought-quote not take? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;polite form⟯
When we're citing thoughts, which verb cannot be in the polite form? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the verb inside the quote⟯
When can the verb inside a direct quote not be in the polite form? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;when we;re citing thoughts⟯
<div class='c1-f'> what's the problem here? </div>雨が降りませんと思います <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;polite form in thought-quote⟯
If we're talking about other people's thoughts, what form must the thinking verb be in? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;ている⟯
ている is necessary for which verbs of thought (in which situation)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;other people thinking⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > although it's possible for your own thoughts too </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What's the problem here? </div>彼はどう思うの? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;thinking verb not in progressive for other person⟯
When quoting/thinking that something is NOT something, what is in the negative? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Either the quoting/thinking verb or the verb in the quote, but not both⟯
<div class='c1-f'> what's the problem here? </div>雨が降らないと思わない。for I don't think it will rain. <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;only one negative pls⟯
What's the difference between <q>negとnot-neg quote verb</q> and <q>not-negとneg quote verb</q> <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the latter sounds more emphatic⟯
what does たとpresent verb, e.g. 面白かったと思う gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;that something was something (e.g. you think that something was cool) but isn't e.g. airing anymore, doesn't exist anymore⟯
<div class="c1-f"> What must be true about やがて君になる? </div><br>「やがて君になる」は面白かったと思う <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c+;it's no longer airing⟯
彼の祖父は偉大な学者だった⟮c+;という⟯。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > contains verb </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >     They say that his grandfather was a great scholar.<br><br> </div> </div>
Besides it's own grammar, what can とする be used for? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;a replacement for と言う・と考える・主張する⟯
と言う・と考える・主張する can be sometimes replaced with what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;とする⟯
<div class='c1-f'> what is とする doing here? </div>キリツグが「僕はね、正義の味方になりたいんだ」とした。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;replacing という⟯
In it's own proper grammar, とする glosses as what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;to presume that⟯
to presume that could be rendered how in japanese? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;とする⟯
<div class='c1-f'> what use of ても is this? </div> 雨が降っていても、ゲームは楽しかった。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;even if, even though⟯
<div class='c1-f'> what use of ても is this? </div>彼が言わなくても、分かるでしょう。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;even if, even though⟯
彼が言わな⟮c+;くても⟯、分かるでしょう。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >       Even if he doesn't say, you'll probably understand.  </div> </div>
⟮c+;　何（なん）と　言（い）っても⟯|⟮c+;no matter what people say, undeniably⟯

What is the relationship between 'japanese women's language' (女性語・女言葉) and the way women 'actually speak'? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Japanese women's language is an ideology that women sometimes speak⟯

In modern hegemonic definitions, how is 女性語・女言葉 said to relate to 女房詞, 遊女語 and other historical forms of languages that some women spoke? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;straight line to today⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > but is not tru </div> </div>
⟮c+;　女房詞（にょうぼうことば）⟯|⟮c+;secret language of court ladies (Muromachi period)⟯
In modern hegemonic definitions, what about women is said to make them speak 女性語・女言葉? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;due to their essential feminity⟯
⟮c+;　社会言語学（しゃかいげんごがく）⟯|⟮c+;sociolinguistics⟯
What is the difference between 男性語 and 女言葉・女性語, in how their use has been regarded (although this is changing)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;男性語 is not a positive norm, but 女言葉・女性語 is⟯
What is evidence for the fact that today 男性語 is not a positive norm, but 女言葉・女性語 is? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Female children are taught to speak 女言葉・女性語, but male children aren't taught to speak 男性語 by their parents⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > however, if we widen 'positive norm', we might include social pressures of manliness for e.g. partner selection, and in that sense 男性語 might be considered to be a positive norm </div> </div>
What is today said of the relationship of 女言葉・女性語 and the beauty of japanese? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;女言葉・女性語 is one of the guarantors of the beuty of japanese⟯
&nbsp;女言葉・女性語 and 男性語 are lects of what kind of japanese (and not of what kind)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;standard language, not of dialects⟯
Very broadly, besides linguistic variants chosen from the standard register, 女言葉・女性語, is said to be characterized by what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;specific 女言葉・女性語-only variants⟯
The fact 女言葉・女性語 contains some kind of prohibition against strong expletives can be seen by what (related to letters 2 the ed)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Letters to the editor complaining about younger women using stuff like ふざけるなよー and うるせー⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > In 1988, a 41-year-old housewife wrote a letter titled, “My daughter said <br>‘Fuzakerunayoo (Go to hell),’” and said: “I was very shocked to hear such vulgar <br>and rough language from my own daughter” (Asahi shimbun, March 23, 1988). <br>Still, in 2006, a 37-year-old housewife wrote another letter titled, “Why does my <br>daughter use dirty speech,” describing the confusion she felt on hearing her daugh-<br>ter say, “Urusee (Shut your trap)!” and wondered, “what is happening in this society?” (Asahi shimbun, July 1, 2006). Responding to the 2006 letter, a 29-year-<br>old female worker wrote, “Parents should scold their children’s dirty speech,” be-<br>fore wondering “what is happening in this society?” (Asahi shimbun, July 4, 2006).  </div> </div>
Etiquette manuals for feminine speech being what is evidence for the currency of 女言葉・女性語? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;them being very popular (constantly on best-seller lists)⟯
Etiquette manuals for feminine speech with titles such as  <q>How a Beauty Speaks: Just One Word, Then You Will Be Loved</q> being very popular shows what aspect of 女言葉・女性語 particularly? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;that speaking 女言葉・女性語 is regarded positively / womanly⟯
女言葉・女性語 is heard far more where than where, today? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;heard far more in media then IRL⟯
since 女言葉・女性語 is more an ideology that women sometimes speak, we might also say it is what, as opposed to what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Knowledge (of what it is) rather than practice⟯
By regarding 女言葉・女性語 as highly interwoven with japan's past, what other feature of 女言葉・女性語 does this cause/strengthen? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;it's supposed value⟯
What idea do all those letters to the editor, by saying how the language women speak has gotten worse 最近, create about the past? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;construct a past when it wasn't so⟯

When counting the units that are 5 or 7&nbsp; long in japanese poetry, what do you use (for the units of 5 or 7, not for the individual sounds, which are 音)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;　句（く）⟯
　句（く） counts what, related to poetry? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the lines of 5 or 7 characters⟯
The possible lengths of 句 japanese poetry are ⟮c+;5⟯ or ⟮c+;7⟯
In a ⟮c+;短歌⟯, the first set of ⟮c+;5-7-5 lines⟯ is called the ⟮c+;　上（かみ）の　句（く）⟯, the second set of ⟮c+;7-7 lines⟯ is called the ⟮c+;　下（しも）の　句（く）.⟯

for compound verbs, by what is the transitivity determined? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;By the first verb⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > (outside of lexicalized compound verbs) </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > https://japanese.stackexchange.com/questions/52801/the-transitivity-of-auxiliary-verbs </div> </div>
for compound verbs, the first verb determines what grammatical thingy? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the transitivity⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > (outside of lexicalized compound verbs) </div> </div>
When is the transitivity of a compound verb not (just) determined by the first verb in the clause? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;lexicalized transitive verbs⟯
In lexicalized compound verbs, what is different to normal compound verbs, as regards transitivity? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the second verb (more often than not) matches the first⟯
In which compound verbs does the transitivity of the second verb (more often than not) match the first? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;lexicalized ones⟯
in compound verbs, which form of the general verb meaning to begin do you almost always use? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;始める⟯
Why is it stem+始める and not +始まる？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;because of an arbitrary rule, and the second verb doesn't matter for transitivity anyway⟯ Whether you use stem+　終（お）える or stem+終わる, is what in relation to the general rule of how the transitivity of compound verbs is determined? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;somewhat of an exception⟯ Whether you use stem+　終（お）える or stem+終わる depends on what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the kind of tone you want to convey⟯ Between stem+　終（お）える or stem+終わる, stem+終<b>え</b>る conveys what nuance and&nbsp; is usually used for <span style="">intentional actions with a purpose</span>? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;a literary nuance⟯ Between stem+　終（お）える or stem+終わる, stem+終<b>え</b>る conveys a literary nuance and is usually used for what kind of actions? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;intentional actions with a purpose⟯ <div class='c1-f'> What's the problem here? </div>食べ出してください。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;stem+出す generally not with commands⟯

⟮c+;stem⟯+⟮c+;かける⟯ most often glosses as ⟮c+;"to be on the verge of verbing"⟯, ⟮c+;"to start verbing and stop in the middle (doing something halfway)"⟯, or ⟮c+;"to do something towards someone"⟯ (but this is only used ⟮c+;with select verbs⟯) Why does 笑いかける mean "To smile at someone"? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;stem+かける as "verb being directed towards someone"⟯

連用形+か<b>か</b>る shares&nbsp; which meaning with +かける? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;to be about to (verb)", "to almost (verb)", "to initiate the action of (verb)ing", etc.⟯ 連用形+か<b>か</b>る shares the 'to initiate action, to almost/be about to verb' meaning of +かける, but... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;none of the other meanings⟯ 連用形+か<b>か</b>る is used how often, compared to + かける? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;less often⟯ 連用形+? to mean'to initiate action, to almost/be about to verb' besides +かける? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;+ かかる⟯ 連用形 + what (starts w k) means to start sth? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;かける・かかる⟯ Why can 呼びかける mean "To address/appeal to someone"? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;because 呼ぶ is one of the verbs that can be used in the 連用形＋かける as directing an action towards someone form.⟯ <div class='c1-f'> What meaning of 連用形かける allows this to mean half-broken music box? </div>壊れかけのオルゴール <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the one where it means stopping midway⟯

When used in listing things, but not for listing things that would just normally take に, in what situations do you use it? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;putting together a list of related things (nouns), adding each one as you go.⟯

with the pattern に adding things as you go (most often trying to recall things), which items get a に? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;all of them but the last one⟯ with the pattern に adding things as you go (most often trying to recall things), how is the last item marked? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;not at all⟯ the most common <b>specific</b>&nbsp;use for に for listing things and adding things as you go is what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;trying to think of things⟯ When you're creating a list trying to think of things, which particle would you use? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;に⟯ What particle is used when putting together a list of related things (nouns), adding each one as you go? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;に⟯ <pre><code>2:「忘れ物は？」 1:「大丈夫ー」 1:「－だと思うけど確認しておこう」 1:「バンデージ⟮c+;に⟯タオル⟮c+;に⟯」 1:「トランクス⟮c+;nada⟯」</code></pre> <div class='c1-f'> since に is used, what feeling does this give? </div>「ほっほっほっ。マックスにイワン。 また、ともに戦う事になってしもうたのう。」 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;feeling of calling names to mind from memory⟯ <div class='c1-f'> Why does the last item here not have a に? </div><pre><code>2:「忘れ物は？」 1:「大丈夫ー」 1:「－だと思うけど確認しておこう」 1:「バンデージにタオルに」 1:「トランクス」</code></pre> <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Because it doesn't in the list where に is used when you're putting together a list of related things (nouns), adding each one as you go⟯ <div class='c1-f'> Why are we using に here? </div>大根ににんじんに、えーと、それからトマトをもらおうかしら。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;putting together a list of related things (nouns), adding each one as you go⟯
<div class='c2-f'> Is? </div><div class='c1-f'> Is sometimes a variant of what particle? </div>⟮c+;variant of は (TOP, CONTRAST):: not copula ⟯|⟮c+;や⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f" > 1 kana </div> </div>
連用形はしない is a stronger version of what? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c+;just any normal negative⟯ 連用形はしない glosses as what? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c+;&nbsp;not verb one bit⟯ To not verb one little bit: ⟮c+;連用形⟯⟮c+;は⟯⟮c+;しない⟯ <div class="c1-f"> Is an instance of which pattern? </div><br>誰にも<b>渡しはせん</b>! <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c+;連用形はしない ⟯ 誰の鍵も合い⟮c+;はしない⟯。<br><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b"> No one's key is fitting<b> at all</b> </div> </div>
宿題が⟮c+;なかなか⟯できなくて、困っています。<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I'm having a hard time doing my homework. </div> </div> なかなか+neg can either mean ... or "not easily/not quite/hard to come by" <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;"by no means"⟯ なかなか+neg can either mean "by no means" or ... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;"not easily/not quite/hard to come by"⟯ <div class='c1-f'> Why is it なかなか here? </div>昨夜、なかなか眠れなかったから。。。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;なかなか+neg as something being hard to come by⟯ "by no means" or "not easily/not quite/hard to come by" could be indicated how? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;なかなか+neg ⟯
さすが(に) can mean, besides '⟮c+;as expected⟯': ⟮c+;even so/all the same (e.g. the taste is good, but when there's this much of it I just am going to tire of it)⟯, ⟮c+;after all (Living on your own is indeed lonely)⟯ <div class='c2-f'> Alternative form of? </div><div class='c1-f'> Alternative form of? </div>⟮c+;さすがに⟯|⟮c+;さすが⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-f">As adverbs</div> </div>

using rare or dialectal 1p pronouns is often a feature of what speech variant? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c+;　役割語（やくわりご）⟯ What may be some of the traits that 　役割語（やくわりご） might convey? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;age, gender, class, occupation ...⟯ The set of language styles that convey certain traits about their speakers such as age, gender, and class and are used mostly in fiction are called? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;　役割語（やくわりご）⟯ 　役割語（やくわりご） is language, often used in fiction, that conveys what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;certain traits about its speaker (such as age, gender, and class)⟯ 　役割語（やくわりご） is language most often used where? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;In works of fiction⟯ ⟮c+;　役割（やくわり）⟯|⟮c+;role⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 2 kanji </div> </div>

⟮c+;　価格革命（かかくかくめい）:: k... (4 kanji) ⟯|⟮c+;The Price Revolution, sometimes known as the Spanish Price Revolution, was a series of economic events that occurred between the second half of the 15th century and the first half of the 17th century, and most specifically linked to the high rate of inflation that occurred during this period across Western Europe. Prices rose on average roughly sixfold over 150 years. This level of inflation amounts to 1–1.5% per year, a relatively low inflation rate for modern-day standards, but rather high given the monetary policy in place in the 16th century.⟯<div class="sub">  </div>

⟮c+;　空耳（そらみみ）⟯|⟮c+;mishearing, feigned deafness, homophonic translation of song lyrics for comic effect ⟯<div class="sub all-b"> Soramimi applies to dialogue as well as song lyrics. For example, in the 2004 film Downfall, when Adolf Hitler says "und betrogen worden", it is misrepresented as "oppai purun purun" ("titty boing boing"). </div> </div>
time nounなtime nounな creates the meaning... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;every &lt;time-noun&gt;⟯ time nounなtime nounな creates the meaning every time noun, but... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;is limited to very few words⟯ the 〜な〜な pattern, even when rarely used with non time nouns seems to imply what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;that there is a lot of the thing in question⟯ the 〜な〜な pattern seems to be used with what, besides time nouns, but very rarely? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;other words⟯ Pattern to create the pattern "every x" (select nouns only): ⟮c+;time noun⟯⟮c+;な⟯⟮c+;time noun⟯⟮c+;な⟯
 ⟮c+;　適（かな）える:: k ... ⟯|⟮c+;to fulfill (conditions); to meet (requirements)​ を⟯ ⟮c+;　適（かな）う⟯|⟮c+;to be suited, to meet with, to match が⟯ ⟮c+;　敵（かな）う⟯|⟮c+;to rival⟯ ⟮c+;　叶（かな）える⟯|⟮c+;grant (a wish), realize (a dream), answer (a prayer) を⟯ ⟮c+;　叶（かな）う⟯|⟮c+;to be fulfilled (a dream, a wish) が⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> compare other kanji spellings 叶う、敵う </div> <div class="sub all-b"> compare different kanji spellings 適う、叶う </div> <div class="sub all-b"> contrast with different kanji spelling 適う </div> <div class="sub all-b"> contrast with different kanji spelling 適う, 敵う </div> </div>

⟮c+;　盆栽（ぼんさい）⟯|⟮c+;is a Japanese version of the original traditional Chinese art penjing or penzai. Unlike penjing, which utilizes traditional techniques to produce entire natural sceneries in small pots that mimic the grandiose and shape of real life sceneries, the Japanese "___" only attempts to produce small trees that mimic the shape of real life trees. Similar versions of the art exist in other cultures, including the miniature living landscapes of Vietnamese Hòn non bộ. It was during the Tang dynasty, when penjing was at its height, that the art was first introduced into Japan.`⟯

when using ⟮c+;方⟯ (⟮c+;the way to⟯) with ⟮c+;する verbs⟯, instead of noun+⟮c+;し方⟯ it is noun⟮c+;の仕方⟯・⟮c+;の方法⟯など<div class="sub"> although it's not inconcievable that the particle の would be dropped, thus making it the same pronunciation, although kanji and origin would be different </div>
<div class='c1-f'> what's the problem here? </div>運転し方 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;should be 運転の仕方 or similar. の might be dropped, but in that case the reason and kanji are still different⟯

Besides meaning "⟮c+;please⟯", ⟮c+;どうか⟯ can also mean ⟮c+;somehow/thing⟯ (via <span class="c2-scr c3-scr">⟮c+;どう⟯+⟮c+;か⟯=⟮c+;somethingifier⟯</span>)
⟮c+;どのように⟯(starts d) is a more polite version of ⟮c+;どう⟯・⟮c+;どうやって⟯・△⟮c+;どうして⟯・など<div class="sub"> I think this holds true for the whole こそあど series, but can't find any evidence rn </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div>どうか許してください。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;please forgive me⟯
Extended from its general meaning of how, ⟮c+;どう⟯ can be used ⟮c+;by itself⟯ as a ⟮c+;casual greeting⟯ ("⟮c+;what's up?⟯") and as a ⟮c+;casual question⟯ ("⟮c+;is it OK?⟯"/"⟮c+;How is it?⟯")
⟮c+;どう⟯ in sentences such as あなたは⟮c+;どう⟯ですか can also mean something like "⟮c+;What about⟯"/"⟮c+;How about⟯" (often used for ⟮c+;suggestions⟯)

⟮c+;なんとかなる⟯ means something like "⟮c+;to manage somehow or other⟯"
い⟮c+;かが⟯ is a ⟮c+;more formal⟯ version of ⟮c+;どう⟯ (and similar words ofc) 
⟮c+;いかん⟯ when from the kanji ⟮c+;如何⟯ may be derivative of ⟮c+;いかに⟯ and either mean the same as ⟮c+;いか（が）⟯ or ⟮c+;however/whysoever⟯
⟮c+;いか⟯、⟮c+;いかん⟯、⟮c+;いかが⟯ and even ⟮c+;どう⟯ may be spelled in kanji as&nbsp;⟮c+;如何⟯
⟮c+;いか⟯ (Kanji: ⟮c+;如何⟯) means "⟮c+;what kind of⟯"
⟮c+;くらい⟯ for asking ”⟮c+;how much?⟯” is often prefixed by ⟮c+;どれ⟯ or ⟮c+;どの⟯
⟮c+;何ぼ⟯ is ⟮c+;関西弁⟯ for ⟮c+;いくら⟯ or ⟮c+;いくつ⟯
The easiest way to think about ⟮c+;いくつ⟯: ⟮c+;いくつ⟯ is the way to ask about things ⟮c+;you would count with つ⟯
⟮c+;いくら:: question word⟯ is most often used for ⟮c+;money⟯, but can also be used to ask about ⟮c+;other quantities⟯
⟮c+;Question word⟯ + X + ⟮c+;(で・て)も⟯ glosses as "⟮c+;no matter...⟯"

Generally ⟮c+;nominalizer の⟯ + ⟮c+;posessive の⟯ = ⟮c+;のの⟯ is ⟮c+;proscribed⟯, but ⟮c+;may rarely happen⟯
Using ⟮c+;の⟯ instead of ⟮c+;が⟯ in relative phrases may give more of a feeling of ⟮c+;belonging⟯ in some cases.
the cause marked by て/で is generally not... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;caused by anyones volition⟯ <div class='c1-f'> what is で doing here? </div>彼は心不全で死んだ。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;marking the cause&nbsp;⟯ <div class='c1-f'> what is で doing here? </div>喜びで我を忘れました。  <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;marking the cause⟯ <div class='c1-f'> what is the て form doing here? </div>彼は愛の足りなくて死んだ。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;marking cause⟯
the ⟮c+;か⟯&nbsp;of かも（しれない）may also become ⟮c+;や⟯ How is かもしれない conjugated? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;As a negative ru verb (but there is no positive)⟯ How is かもしれない sometimes written with Kanji? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;かも知れない⟯ What is the hypermasculine version of かもしれない? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;かもしれん⟯ What is the polite present form of かもしれない? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;かもしれません⟯ What is かもしれない abbreviated to in casual speech? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;かも⟯ What do you attach to the end of the clause to express uncertainty (at the level of 'possibly')? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;かもしれない⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > since it's based off 知る </div> <div class="sub c1-f" > Long ver </div> </div>

これ・あれ・それ are pluralized using ⟮c+;ら⟯, ⟮c+;but relatively rarely.⟯
⟮c+;頂く⟯ is ⟮c+;謙譲語⟯ for ⟮c+;食べる⟯ or ⟮c+;もらう⟯
⟮c+;頂く⟯ ⟮c+;non-humbly⟯ means ⟮c+;to place on or above ones head⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What use of てもらう is this? </div>自分で出したゴミが、自分で持って帰ってもらいます。 <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c+;to have someone do something⟯
Generally, the negative of ⟮c+;知っている⟯ is&nbsp;⟮c+;知らない⟯ , though ⟮c+;知っていない⟯ may occur when&nbsp; &nbsp;⟮c+;知っている⟯&nbsp;&nbsp;is ⟮c+;also used in the same sentence⟯, or ⟮c+;in dialects⟯ 
between ⟮c+;匹⟯ and ⟮c+;頭⟯, generally ⟮c+;頭⟯ counts ⟮c+;larger animals⟯ than ⟮c+;匹⟯
⟮c+;　羽（わ (ば sometimes for some numbers)）⟯ counts ⟮c+;birds⟯ and ⟮c+;rabbits⟯
⟮c+;箇⟯ is often replaced with ⟮c+;ヶ⟯/⟮c+;ヵ⟯ (both read ⟮c+;か⟯)

kanji for ⟮c+;すごい⟯ is ⟮c+;<span style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34);">凄</span>い⟯
⟮c+;small round things such as grains, seeds, pills, drops⟯ are counted with  ⟮c+;　粒（つぶ）⟯ ⟮c+;overnight stays⟯ are counted with  ⟮c+;　泊（はく）⟯ ⟮c+;messages⟯ or ⟮c+;official documents⟯ are counted with  ⟮c+;　通（つう）⟯ ⟮c+;clothes⟯ are counted with  ⟮c+;　着（ちゃく）⟯ ⟮c+;words⟯ are counted with ⟮c+;　語（ご）⟯ ⟮c+;volumes (of a series of books, videotapes, films, etc)⟯ are counted with ⟮c+;　巻（かん）⟯ ⟮c+;songs⟯ are counted with ⟮c+;　曲（きょく）⟯ ⟮c+;slices, cuts, mochi⟯ are counted with ⟮c+;　切（き）れ⟯ ⟮c+;servings (and sometimes empty plates)⟯ are counted with ⟮c+;　皿（さら）⟯ ⟮c+;schools⟯ and weirdly ⟮c+;corrections in proofreading⟯ are counted with ⟮c+;　校（こう）⟯ ⟮c+;matches (esp. of japanese sports)⟯ are counted with ⟮c+;　試合（しあい）⟯ ⟮c+;languages⟯ (esp. ⟮c+;national⟯ ones) are counted with ⟮c+;ヶ/ヵ/箇　国語（こくご）⟯ ⟮c+;food items⟯ and sometimes ⟮c+;dishes (of food)⟯ are counted with ⟮c+;品 (しな/ひん)⟯ ⟮c+;countries⟯ are counted with ⟮c+;ヶ/ヵ/箇　国（こく）⟯ ⟮c+;cases, instances, matters⟯ are counted with ⟮c+;　件（けん）⟯ ⟮c+;cans⟯ are counted with ⟮c+;　缶（かん）⟯ ⟮c+;buildings, addresses⟯ are counted with ⟮c+;　軒（けん）⟯ ⟮c+;bites, sips⟯ and ⟮c+;swords⟯, ⟮c+;shares of money⟯ are counted with ⟮c+;　口（くち）⟯ ⟮c+;stories, episodes, chapters⟯ are counted with  ⟮c+;　話（わ）⟯ ⟮c+;rooms⟯ are counted with  ⟮c+;　部屋（へや）⟯ ⟮c+;questions⟯&nbsp; are counted with  ⟮c+;　問（もん）⟯ ⟮c+;long-distance trips (flights, boats, buses, etc.)⟯ are counted with  ⟮c+;　便（びん）⟯ ⟮c+;boxes of whatever (nless small dispoasable meal boxes)⟯ are counted by ⟮c+;　箱（はこ）⟯ ⟮c+;bags, pouches (with whatever contents)⟯ are counted with  ⟮c+;　袋（ふくろ）⟯ besides liquids in cups/bowls, ⟮c+;squid, cuttlefish, crabs⟯ and ⟮c+;various ships (sometimes)⟯ are counted with  ⟮c+;　杯（はい）⟯
⟮c+;　頭皮（とうひ）⟯|⟮c+;scalp⟯
⟮c+;すっきり⟯ can&nbsp;mean ⟮c+;refreshed/ing(ly)⟯, ⟮c+;clean/clear/neat(ly)⟯, ⟮c+;refined(ly)⟯, ⟮c+;completely/thoroughly⟯&nbsp;
~⟮c+;たい⟯ in kanji is ⟮c+;度い⟯
between ⟮c+;を⟯ and ⟮c+;が⟯ for ⟮c+;たい⟯(wanting), the ⟮c+;prescriptive⟯ position is that ⟮c+;が⟯ is ⟮c+;the only acceptable particle⟯ with ⟮c+;たい⟯, ⟮c+;in fact⟯ ⟮c+;を⟯ is ⟮c+;also used⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What's the problem here? </div>セスは日本での生活が懐かしいです。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;we can't just say what someone is feeling, we need to use 〜がる⟯
がる can often (though not always) convey what kind of tone? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+; a kind of negative/complaney tone⟯
when&nbsp; talking about other people,&nbsp; ⟮c+;verbs⟯ (even when expressing feelings, etc) ⟮c+;don't need⟯ ⟮c+;がる⟯⟮c+;adjectives⟯ ⟮c+;often need⟯ ⟮c+;がる&nbsp;⟯
When talking about the ⟮c+;feelings (and feeling-adjacent things)⟯ of ⟮c+;other people⟯ (or ⟮c+;oneself⟯ as ⟮c+;seen from the outside⟯, e.g. the ⟮c+;past⟯) you use ⟮c+;がる⟯ (at least for ⟮c+;adjectives⟯)
Using ⟮c+;てみたい⟯ instead of ⟮c+;たい⟯ is ⟮c+;more frequent⟯ than ⟮c+;"to want to try"⟯ is in english.
⟮c+;only some⟯ adjectives are frequently/ever used with がる
⟮c+;がる⟯ can also sometimes be used when you want someone to act a certain way (or not) based on their feelings
~⟮c+;がり⟯ can be used for someone who is adjectively (with no ⟮c+;critical⟯ nuance) ⟮c+;恥ずかしがり屋⟯|⟮c+;one who easily feels embarrased⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> http://www.guidetojapanese.org/learn/grammar/signs </div> </div> ⟮c+;寒がり屋⟯|⟮c+;one who easily feels cold⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> http://www.guidetojapanese.org/learn/grammar/signs </div> </div> the がり屋 pattern is generally ⟮c+;critical⟯-sounding, especially so if you add ⟮c+;さん⟯ <div>How would one say someone who easily feels adjective?</div> <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c+;<span class="highlightMain">adjective</span><span class="highlightMain">～がり</span><span class="highlightMain">屋</span>⟯ Act scared <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c+;怖がる<br>⟯ For whom is the 欲しい／たい form + がる generally used? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c+;Observe what another person wants⟯ What do you use to say that someone is acting &lt;some adjective&gt;, for I-adjectives? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c+;<span class="highlightMain">i-adj - i</span><span class="highlightMain">がる</span>⟯ What do you use to say that someone is acting &lt;some adjective&gt;, for な-adjectives? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c+;<span class="highlightMain">na-adj</span><span class="highlightMain">がる</span>⟯ What does <span class="highlightMain">adjective</span><span class="highlightMain">～がり</span><span class="highlightMain">屋</span> gloss as? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c+;Someone who easily feels adjective⟯
((h:all;::<img src="onjoA.png">))x⟮c+;のこと⟯ has two aspects, one that ⟮c+;increases the scope of⟯ x, and one that ⟮c+;adds focus⟯ to x<div class="sub"> the circle is x </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What's the difference in nuance here, vs. just あなたが好き？ </div>あなたのことが好き <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;adds a feeling of liking everything encompassing the person (scope-widening) and of this being the exact person one likes (focusing)⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What's the difference in nuance here, vs. just パンが好き? </div>パンのことが好き <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;adds a feeling of liking everything everything about bread (scope-widening) and of bread being the specific thing one likes (focusing)⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What's the difference in nuance here, vs. just 事件がよく覚えてます。? </div>事件のことがよく覚えてます。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;adds a feeling of remembering a whole universe of facts around the case (scope-widening) the case being very present (focusing)⟯

⟮c+;stem⟯ + ⟮c+;込む⟯ can mean ⟮c+;to verb in/into⟯ (e.g. ⟮c+;to blow in, to jump in⟯), ⟮c+;to verb fully/deeply/intensly⟯, or ⟮c+;to verb and then continue in the same manner⟯ 　黙（だま）り　込（こ）む uses what meaning of the stem + 込む pattern? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;to fall silent -&gt; to do an action and then stay that way⟯ 　飛（と）び　込（こ）む uses what meaning of the stem + 込む pattern? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;Jump in/Dive. -&gt; to verb in/into⟯ 　思（おも）い　込（こ）む uses what meaning of the stem + 込む pattern? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;be convinced, have one's heart set on -&gt; intensification meaning&nbsp;⟯ 　吹（ふ）き　込（こ）む uses what meaning of the stem + 込む pattern? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;to blow in -&gt; verbing in/into meaning⟯
　教（おし）え　込（こ）む means what why? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;to teach thoroughly, instill, inculcate (連用形 + 込む pattern)⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Verb for? </div>to push into (using pattern) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;押し込む⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Verb for? </div>to read thoroughly; read into, read into memory (using pattern) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;読み込む⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Verb for? </div>to promote, to do a hard sell, find a market for (using pattern) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;　売（う）り　込（こ）む⟯

⟮c+;　瞳（ひとみ）⟯|⟮c+;pupil (of eye), (poetic) eye⟯
⟮c+;　倭（わ）　寇（こう）⟯|⟮c+;pirates from a mixture of ethnicities but said to be japanese who raided the coastlines of China and Korea from the 13th to 16th centuries⟯
the ⟮c+;わ⟯ (⟮c+;wo⟯ in chinese) meaning ⟮c+;Japan⟯ was originally written ⟮c+;倭⟯ meaning ⟮c+;midget⟯. Since ⟮c+;the japanese didn't like referring to themselves using a pejorative term⟯, in the ⟮c+;700⟯s they looked for a kanji with ⟮c+;the same reading⟯ but ⟮c+;a different meaning⟯ and hit on ⟮c+;和⟯.
in general where possible japanese will prefer long compound terms to be ⟮c+;four-character⟯ compounds
Why is it 和製漢語 and not 日本製漢語? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;because japanese generally prefers for character compounds⟯

In modern Japan, the term is most often used in reference to independent volumes of a single manga series: most series first appear as individual chapters in a weekly or monthly manga magazine with other works before being collected into ___⟯

⟮c+;連用形⟯＋⟮c+;出す⟯ can either mean to ⟮c+;start something suddenly⟯, or to ⟮c+;make something reveal/appear outside or on the surface by doing the action⟯ ⟮c+;　見出（みいだ）す (notice the kana)⟯&nbsp;means ⟮c+;find out/discover/notice⟯, ⟮c+;select⟯, ⟮c+;to be wide-eyed (in surprise, anger)⟯, and (grammatically obvious) ⟮c+;to look out⟯ <div class='c1-f'> What meaning of 連用形＋出す are we using here? </div>　引（ひ）き　出（だ）す <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;To verb something out of something⟯ <div class='c1-f'> What meaning of 連用形＋出す are we using here? </div>　助（たす）け　出（だ）す <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;the one where it means to verb something out of something⟯

⟮c+;あまり・あんまり⟯ in kanji is ⟮c+;余り⟯
⟮c+;余り⟯, besides the kanji spelling of the adverb ⟮c+;あまり・あんまり⟯, means the ⟮c+;remainder⟯, an ⟮c+;excess of⟯, and after ⟮c+;a number⟯ may mean "a ⟮c+;little more than⟯", and archaically would have ⟮c+;connected the parts of a number large than the base (10 and 5, 100 and 30 and 7)⟯

⟮c+;　訪（おとず）れる⟯|⟮c+;visit, call on, pay somewhere a visit; for an occurence to come, arrive⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-b c1-f" > <pre><code>The subject can be either animate (e.g. a person) or inanimate (e.g. an occurrence or season). The object cannot be animate, or else it should be phrased as "someone's location" or "someone's time". The action can be either on purpose or arbitrary. Consequentially, the intention of the action is left ambiguous unless otherwise stated.</code></pre> </div> </div>

⟮c+;　煮詰（につ）める⟯|⟮c+;to boil down; to concentrate (soup, milk, stock, etc.); bring a discussion to a conclusion⟯
⟮c+;鼻詰まり⟯|⟮c+;congestion of the nose⟯
⟮c+;つまらない⟯ is descended from the verb ⟮c+;詰まる⟯ and can besides the most common meaning ⟮c+;boring⟯ also mean ⟮c+;trivial, insignificant⟯ or ⟮c+;absurd, foolish⟯ 
⟮c+;つまり⟯ in kanji is ⟮c+;詰まり⟯, which as a noun can also mean ⟮c+;obstruction, clogging⟯;  ⟮c+;shrinkage⟯; ⟮c+;dead end⟯; ⟮c+;distress⟯
a synonym of ⟮c+;詰まり⟯&nbsp;is ⟮c+;詰まるところ⟯
⟮c+;　詰（つ）め　合（あ）わせ⟯|⟮c+;assortment; putting different kinds of items in a box, basket, etc.; or such a collection⟯

⟮c+;　甘（あま）い/うまい　汁（しる）を　吸（す）う⟯|⟮c+;to line one's pockets⟯
⟮c+;　我慢汁（がまんじる）⟯|⟮c+;precum⟯
⟮c+;　出（だ）し or 　出（だ）　汁（し） (cooking context)⟯|⟮c+;) is a family of stocks used in Japanese cuisine. Dashi forms the base for miso soup, clear broth soup, noodle broth soup, and many simmering liquids to accentuate the savory flavor known as umami. The most common form of dashi is a simple broth made by heating water containing kombu (edible kelp) and kezurikatsuo (shavings of katsuobushi – preserved, fermented skipjack tuna or bonito) to near-boiling, then straining the resultant liquid; dried anchovies or sardines may be substituted.⟯
⟮c+;　研（と）ぐ⟯|⟮c+;sharpen, whet an ax or knife;  wash rice; polish, clean a surface を⟯
⟮c+;　白（しろ）　水（みず）⟯|⟮c+;whitish water that has been used to wash rice⟯
⟮c+;　肉汁（にくじゅう） / 　肉（にく）　汁（じる）⟯|⟮c+;meat broth, juice, gravy⟯

⟮c+;　漏（も）れ⟯|⟮c+;variant of 俺⟯<div class="sub"> <div class='sub f'> online slang </div> </div>
⟮c+;お　漏（も）らし⟯|⟮c+;wetting oneself, The sexual fetish of arousal from having a full bladder or a sexual attraction to someone else experiencing the feeling of a full urinary bladder., (informal) information leakage⟯
⟮c+;　聞（き）き　漏（も）らす ::k...⟯|⟮c+;to fail to hear; to miss (also in a metaphorical sense)⟯
⟮c+;　木（こ）　漏（も）れ　日（び）⟯|⟮c+;sunlight filtering through trees ⟯
words that contain ⟮c+;も⟯ as ⟮c+;漏⟯ may also spell it ⟮c+;洩⟯
⟮c+;Final vowel sounds of morphemes⟯ in ⟮c+;compounds⟯ may sometimes ⟮c+;change to a different vowel⟯ compared to their more common readings, most commonly either due to ⟮c+;ancient readings or patterns being preserved⟯, ⟮c+;assimilation⟯, or ⟮c+;casual/local readings becoming fossilized&nbsp;⟯<div class="sub"> e.g. あまぞら (vs *あめぞら), さかや (vs *さけや), こもれび (vs *きもれび) </div>
the ⟮c+;copula⟯ in ⟮c+;文語⟯ was/is ⟮c+;なり⟯
the ⟮c+;文語 copula なり⟯ would only be ⟮c+;なり⟯ (instead of ⟮c+;なる⟯) in the ⟮c+;終止形⟯, where it could have been spelled ⟮c+;也⟯
the ⟮c+;文語 copula なり⟯&nbsp; evolved from even older ⟮c+;に+あり⟯
One of the about five million options for ⟮c+;listing either ... or options⟯ is ⟮c+;〜なり〜なり⟯ (contains an n)
often when using the ⟮c+;〜なり〜なり⟯ (contains n) pattern, the ⟮c+;final element⟯ is ⟮c+;a question word⟯ implying ⟮c+;some....⟯
⟮c+;なり⟯ after ⟮c+;a single option⟯ implies ⟮c+;there might be other options, as in giving an example⟯
<div class='c2-f'> what pattern are we using here for what meaning? </div><div class='c1-f'> What might be an example for this pattern? </div>⟮c+;楽天なりどこなりで買い物をする⟯|⟮c+;〜なり〜なり for listing options⟯
<div class='c2-f'> what pattern are we using here for what meaning? </div><div class='c1-f'> What might be an example for this pattern? </div>⟮c+;労働局になり相談したらどうですか⟯|⟮c+;なり：or something, for example⟯
⟮c+;verb (dictionary form)⟯ + ⟮c+;なり⟯ = ⟮c+;as soon as⟯
⟮c+;verb (past tense)⟯ + ⟮c+;なり⟯ = ⟮c+;while⟯
<div class='c1-f'> means what why? </div>彼は帰るなり、トイレに行った。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;He went to the bathroom <b>as soon as</b>&nbsp;he got home (なり: as soon as pattern)⟯
<div class='c1-f'> means what why? </div>帰るなり座った <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;sat down as soon as I got home (v+なり: as soon as pattern)⟯
⟮c+;　並木（なみき）⟯|⟮c+;roadside tree, row of roadside trees⟯
⟮c+;　並木道（なみきみち）⟯|⟮c+;avenue; boulevard; tree-lined street⟯
⟮c+;オブラートに　包（つつ）む⟯|⟮c+;to sugarcoat (to say something in a way not to upset)⟯
⟮c+;オブラート⟯|⟮c+;oblaten⟯
⟮c+;　肉離（にくばな）れ⟯|⟮c+;pulled or torn muscle⟯
⟮c+;ギンギン⟯|⟮c+;enthusiastic, noisy barking/chirping, splitting headache⟯

⟮c+;　流（なが）れ⟯&nbsp;is a ⟮c+;flow⟯ of things in both the ⟮c+;literal⟯ and ⟮c+;figurative⟯ sense, in specific it can also mean the ⟮c+;course of events⟯, ⟮c+;a group of people who remain together at the end of an event⟯, ⟮c+;descent/ancestry/school(of thought)⟯, ⟮c+;forfeiture/forclosure⟯, ⟮c+;drifting/wandering/roaming⟯
⟮c+;戯れる⟯ can mean ⟮c+;to play with, joke, frolic, be amused with⟯ or ⟮c+;to flirt with, to dally⟯. It can be read ⟮c+;たわ⟯(⟮c+;む⟯・⟮c+;ぶ⟯)⟮c+;れる⟯ or (⟮c+;ざ⟯・⟮c+;じゃ⟯)⟮c+;れる⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b">It's no joke to send people to war with an empty flame spear. Without a weapon, they might die. Who will you flirt with then, huh?</div> </div>
⟮c+;イチャイチャ⟯|⟮c+;flirting, making out⟯

⟮c+;　薬玉（くすだま）⟯|⟮c+; decorative ball of cloth or paper flowers with long streamers;  a ball-shaped, scented bag⟯
⟮c+;ヶ⟯ is generally a(n) ⟮c+;abbreviation⟯ of ⟮c+;箇⟯, but may also be a(n) ⟮c+;abbreviation⟯ of ⟮c+;個⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b">which makes sense, as 箇 is the 旧字体 form of 個</div> </div>
In cases where ⟮c+;送り仮名⟯ are written in ⟮c+;small 片仮名⟯, ⟮c+;ヶ⟯ is nevertheless read ⟮c+;け⟯
⟮c+;　条（じょう）⟯ or ⟮c+;　箇（か）　条（じょう）⟯&nbsp;is used to count numbers of ⟮c+;items⟯, and esp. ⟮c+;articles⟯/⟮c+;clauses⟯/⟮c+;sections⟯
When counting ⟮c+;languages⟯ without ⟮c+;concern whether they are national languages (or not)⟯, one uses ⟮c+;　言語（げんご）⟯
⟮c+;　箇（か）　条（じょう）⟯|⟮c+;item; article; clause; section; point⟯
⟮c+;　箇条書（かじょうが）き⟯|⟮c+;itemized form, itemization, bullet point⟯
⟮c+;　教（きょう）　条（じょう）⟯|⟮c+;dogma, doctrine⟯
⟮c+;　条件付（じょうけんつ）き⟯|⟮c+;conditionally; with conditions attached⟯
⟮c+;　条項（じょうこう）⟯|⟮c+;clause; article; stipulations⟯
⟮c+;　条約（じょうやく）⟯|⟮c+;treaty⟯
⟮c+;　条例（じょうれい）/　条（じょう）　令（れい）⟯|⟮c+;regulations, ordinance, by-law⟯
⟮c+;　信条（しんじょう）⟯|⟮c+;creed; belief; conviction; article of faith⟯
⟮c+;　不条理（ふじょうり）⟯|⟮c+;absurd, incongruous, unreasonable, unjust⟯
⟮c+;　条理（じょうり）⟯|⟮c+;logic; reasoning⟯
⟮c+;　不平等条約（ふびょうどうじょうやく）⟯|⟮c+;unequal treaty (treaty forced upon weaker nations by imperialist power)⟯
⟮c+;　不（ふ）　平（びょう）　等（どう）⟯|⟮c+;unequal⟯
⟮c+;Sino-Xenic⟯ = related to ⟮c+;漢字⟯ (and esp. ⟮c+;their pronunciation⟯) in ⟮c+;Japan⟯, ⟮c+;Korea⟯, and ⟮c+;Vietnam⟯ (= not ⟮c+;in chinese or its dialects⟯)
⟮c+;　関（せき）ヶ　原（はら）⟯&nbsp;is read ⟮c+;せきがはら⟯, because ⟮c+;the middle character is a way to write the old posessive が⟯
⟮c+;連用形⟯＋⟮c+;暮らす⟯ is to ⟮c+;go through the whole day doing something⟯<div class="sub"> man, notice the exact parallel between this and -明かす, its exactly like the くろ - あか distinction! </div> ⟮c+;連用形⟯＋⟮c+;明かす⟯ is to ⟮c+;go through the whole night doing something⟯ ⟮c+;泣き暮らす⟯ = ⟮c+;to cry the whole day⟯ (due to grammar) ⟮c+;　暮（く）れる⟯|⟮c+;for night to fall (prob. original meaning), season ending, be lost in/overwhelmed by an emotion/thought が⟯ ⟮c+;　暮（く）れ　泥（なず）む⟯|⟮c+;to become twilight, (of a sunset) to linger⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 2 kanji 2 kana </div> </div> ⟮c+;　暮（く）らす⟯|⟮c+;spend (the daytime of a day, or a long time); by extension: lead a life を⟯ ⟮c+;　暮（く）らし ::1 kanji 2 kana⟯|⟮c+;life; living; livelihood; life circumstances⟯ ⟮c+;　日（ひ）　暮（ぐ）れ⟯|⟮c+;sunset, sundown, dusk, evening, nightfall⟯ ⟮c+;　日（ひ）　暮（ぐ）らし⟯|⟮c+;from morning to evening, all day⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 2 kanji 2 kana, h... </div> </div> ⟮c+;　夕（ゆう）　暮（ぐ）れ⟯|⟮c+;evening twilight, evening when the sun goes down⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > y..., 2 kanji 1 kana </div> </div> ⟮c+;　一（ひと）　人（り）　暮（ぐ）らし⟯|⟮c+;living by oneself; living alone⟯ ⟮c+;　途方（とほう）に　暮（く）れる⟯|⟮c+;to be at a loss⟯ ⟮c+;　暮（く）らしを　立（た）てる⟯|⟮c+;to make a living⟯ ⟮c+;　日（ひ）　暮（く）れて　道（みち）　遠（とお）し⟯|⟮c+;arduous is the race against time as one grows old.⟯ ⟮c+;くろ⟯ probably became '⟮c+;black⟯' as a consequence of its '⟮c+;darkening after sunset⟯' meaning ⟮c+;あか⟯ probably became '⟮c+;red⟯' as a consequence of its '⟮c+;brightening at dawn (think morning glow)⟯' meaning the ⟮c+;four⟯ colors that exist as ⟮c+;1⟯-kanji ⟮c+;い⟯adjectives: ⟮c+;黒⟯、⟮c+;白⟯、⟮c+;赤⟯、⟮c+;青⟯ can also be used as ⟮c+;のadjectives⟯ in ⟮c+;highly restricted⟯ circumstances the colors that have existed in japan since ⟮c+;ancient times⟯ are ⟮c+;黒⟯、⟮c+;白⟯、⟮c+;赤⟯、⟮c+;青⟯ (they are, not coincidentally, also ⟮c+;the only ones that you can use as 形容詞⟯). The others have either been ⟮c+;repurposed⟯ far more ⟮c+;recently⟯ from ⟮c+;plants, materials⟯ or ⟮c+;borrowed from languages such as english⟯ Under the assumption of the 4-color ancient japanese color system, the pairs of ⟮c+;opposites⟯ probably would have been (!) ⟮c+;あか⟯ - ⟮c+;くろ⟯ and ⟮c+;あを⟯ - ⟮c+;しろ⟯ It is argued that in ⟮c+;ancient japan⟯, there was a ⟮c+;color system (not a technical term)⟯ where ⟮c+;bright colors⟯ would have been ⟮c+;あか⟯, ⟮c+;dark colors⟯ would have been ⟮c+;くろ⟯, ⟮c+;indistinct and vague colors⟯ would have been ⟮c+;あを (today あお)⟯, and ⟮c+;distinct colors⟯ would have been ⟮c+;しろ⟯ It is argued that the color word ⟮c+;赤⟯（⟮c+;あか⟯）is etymologically related to ⟮c+;朱⟯（⟮c+;あけ⟯, '⟮c+;crimson⟯'） and ⟮c+;明ける⟯・⟮c+;明るい⟯・など, originally having a meaning such as '⟮c+;brightening at dawn⟯' It is argued that the color word ⟮c+;白⟯ （⟮c+;しろ⟯）is related etymologcially to ⟮c+;印⟯（⟮c+;しるし⟯, '⟮c+;mark⟯'）、⟮c+;白白⟯（⟮c+;しらしら⟯, ⟮c+;'obvious speech⟯' (originally)） It is argued that the color word ⟮c+;くろ⟯（⟮c+;黒⟯）is etymologically related to ⟮c+;　暮（く）れる⟯&nbsp;(and related words) and ⟮c+;暗い⟯ （⟮c+;くらい⟯） (and related words) and meant something such as '⟮c+;darkening after sunset⟯' ⟮c+;　藍（あい）⟯|⟮c+;indigo (plant, color)⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> clearly related with あお via the older reading あを </div> </div> ⟮c+;しるし⟯ may mean ⟮c+;mark/sign/badge/crest/flag/symbol/emblen⟯ (then often spelled ⟮c+;印⟯ or ⟮c+;徴⟯ or ⟮c+;標⟯) or ⟮c+;evidence/proof⟯ (then often spelled ⟮c+;証⟯ and also read ⟮c+;あかし⟯)<div class="sub"> hey look, a connection between しろ and あか </div> ⟮c+;あか⟯ meaning ⟮c+;red⟯ is less commonly also spelled ⟮c+;朱⟯ ⟮c+;　赤裸（あかはだか）⟯|⟮c+;stark naked; nude; bare; unvarnished (e.g. truth); plain (e.g. fact); frank; candid; outspoken⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> uses the あか as bright, exposed original meaning </div><div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > may also be read as せきら and also be realized as&nbsp; 赤裸々 </div> </div> ⟮c+;　赤（せき）　面（めん）⟯|⟮c+;blushing⟯ ⟮c+;　赤（あか）の　他人（たにん）⟯|⟮c+;a complete stranger⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> via the older meaning of あか as bright, clear </div> </div> ⟮c+;　赤（あか）　字（じ）⟯|⟮c+;red characters (literally), (by extension) deficit; To refer to an ⟮c+;inbetween-shade of color⟯, ⟮c+;list the two colors after each other⟯. the resultant compound can be read with ⟮c+;either 訓読み or 音読み⟯, but ⟮c+;the former⟯ is ⟮c+;more common⟯.
⟮c+;黄緑⟯ means ⟮c+;yellow-green⟯, and may be read either ⟮c+;きみどり⟯ or ⟮c+;おうりょく⟯ (due to grammar)
⟮c+;light/pale⟯ colors are indicated either by adding the adjectives ⟮c+;　淡（あわ）い⟯&nbsp;or ⟮c+;　薄（うす）い⟯&nbsp;or by ⟮c+;prefixing 　薄（うす）.⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Means? </div>    　淡（あわ）い黄色 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;pale yellow⟯ 　薄（うす）い　色（いろ） <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c+;light/pale color⟯ of the ⟮c+;color words⟯ that are ⟮c+;compounds⟯ that ⟮c+;end in 色⟯, depending on ⟮c+;the color⟯ (and the grammatical / conversational situation) it may be ⟮c+;more or less acceptable⟯ to ⟮c+;leave the final 色 out.⟯ ⟮c+;<ruby> 茜色 <rp>(</rp><rt>あかねいろ</rt><rp>)</rp> </ruby>⟯|⟮c2;⟯ ⟮c+;　渋色（しぶいろ）⟯|⟮c+;tan (color)⟯ ⟮c+;　灰色（はいいろ）⟯|⟮c+;ash color, gray⟯ ⟮c+;　緑色（みどりいろ）⟯|⟮c+;green⟯ ⟮c+;　色名（しきめい）⟯|⟮c+;color name, color term⟯ ⟮c+;　茶色（ちゃいろ）⟯|⟮c+;light brown⟯ ⟮c+;　藍色（あいいろ）⟯|⟮c+;the color indigo⟯ ⟮c+;　金色（きんいろ）⟯|⟮c+;gold (color)⟯ ⟮c+;　顔（かお）　色（いろ）⟯|⟮c+;complexion, the appearance of one's face due to skin color or blood flow; facial expression⟯ ⟮c+;　黄色（きいろ）⟯|⟮c+;yellow⟯ ⟮c+;　黄色（きいろ）い⟯|⟮c+;yellow⟯ ⟮c+;バラ色⟯|⟮c+;bright (e.g. life, future, prospects); cheerful; rosy⟯ ⟮c+;バラ色⟯|⟮c+;rose-color(ed)⟯ ⟮c+;ベージュ(色)⟯|⟮c+;beige⟯ ⟮c+;濃い緑色⟯ = ⟮c+;dark green⟯ ⟮c+;　 色 （いろ）⟯|⟮c2;⟯ <div class="sub all-b"> The sky's gray today. </div><div class="sub all-b"> He's wearing a green jacket. </div><div class="sub c1-f" > also 緑 </div><div class="sub all-b"> "Tea-color" </div><div class="sub c1-f" > 2 kanji </div> <div class="sub all-b"> The traffic light was yellow. </div><div class="sub all-b"> Pretending to be a KIIten while pissing yellow liquid is pretty eROI. </div><div class="sub c2-b c1-f" > Adjective </div> <div class="sub all-b"> Oreki's 'rose-colored' student life </div><div class="sub c2-f" > figurativel </div><div class="sub c1-f" > 2 kata 1 kanji </div> <div class="sub c2-f" > literal meaning </div> </div>

⟮c+;　影（かげ）が/の　薄（うす）い⟯|⟮c+;in the background; not standing out⟯
to express that a color is ⟮c+;deep/dark⟯, use ⟮c+;　濃（こ）い⟯
⟮c+;　青（あお）⟯ is today mostly described as '⟮c+;blue⟯', however in ⟮c+;the past⟯ it would have also included ⟮c+;green⟯, as seen in ⟮c+;many compounds::type of word⟯. Even ⟮c+;today⟯, it encompasses part of what english speakers would&nbsp; call ⟮c+;green⟯.
besides ⟮c+;blue⟯ and ⟮c+;green⟯, ⟮c+;あお⟯ in the past might also have included other colors, e.g ⟮c+;black⟯ and ⟮c+;indigo⟯ (whence ⟮c+;　藍（あい）⟯)
⟮c+;青⟯ gathered a connotation with ⟮c+;youth and freshness⟯, probably via ⟮c+;青春⟯
⟮c+;青⟯ has been retained as ⟮c+;green⟯ more commonly in ⟮c+;fixed expressions⟯, esp. in relation to ⟮c+;plants⟯ and ⟮c+;traffic lights⟯
⟮c+;　青物（あおもの）⟯|⟮c+;greens, green vegetables, (just) vegetables⟯

 ⟮c+;　仏壇（ぶつだん）⟯|⟮c+; is a shrine commonly found in temples and homes in Japanese Buddhist cultures.[1] A ___ is either a defined, often ornate platform or simply a wooden cabinet sometimes crafted with doors that enclose and protect a Gohonzon or religious icon, typically a statue or painting of a Buddha or Bodhisattva, or a calligraphic mandala scroll. Its primary use is for paying respects to the Buddha, as well as to family members who have died.⟯

⟮c+;　交際（こうさい）⟯|⟮c+;association; relationship; dating, going out with someone⟯
⟮c+;　援助交際（えんじょこうさい） often shortened to 　援（えん）　交（こう）⟯|⟮c+;dating with compensation (payments, financial support, etc.); schoolgirl prostitution.⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-b c1-f" > A 1997 poll in the Japanese TV Asahi program Asa Made Nama Terebi [ja] showed that 70 percent of respondents opposed enjo-kōsai involving sexual interactions, while 30 percent approved of it.[6] Typically, it is perceived as an extension of Japan's growing focus on materialism, much of which is what critics claim is the cause of enjo-kōsai. Critics worry that girls involved in enjo-kōsai will grow up to be unfit wives and mothers. This perception arises from suspicions that when these girls are adults, they will quickly abandon their loyalties and commitments to their family for offers of money and material benefits.[6] However, certain feminist groups[which?] and critics regard enjo-kōsai as an empowering way to "undermine patriarchal models of propriety used to evaluate and control women".[This quote needs a citation] Control over their bodies and means to support themselves is a new kind of independence for these girls. Good women in Japan are supposed to be sensible, modest, nurturing and respectful, yet girls participating in enjo-kōsai clearly reject such virtues of female restraint and modesty in Japan. Feminists such as Chizuko Ueno point out that the accidental access of girls to this dating market was not a matter of ethics, but of probability.[6] Sooner or later, these girls and young women would, in a desire for financial independence, tap into this market for their own empowerment. However, Ueno points out that while engaging in enjo-kōsai may appear beneficial for young women in the short term, it also reinforces patriarchal power structures by leaving the notion that women's bodies exist to serve male desire unchallenged.[7] </div> </div>

⟮c+;　歯（は）　車（ぐるま）⟯|⟮c+;gear, cog⟯
in the case of ⟮c+;破⟯, the ones with ⟮c+;k as the first letter of the okurigana⟯ (that is, ⟮c+;く and ける⟯)&nbsp; ⟮c+;are (generally) semantically restricted to tearing⟯, while those with ⟮c+;r as the first letter of the okurigana⟯ (that is, ⟮c+;る and れる⟯) ⟮c+;can either have a tearing meaning, but also a meaning of breaking or defeating⟯. The ones ⟮c+;ending -u with one kana⟯ (that is, ⟮c+;く and る⟯) are ⟮c+;intransitive (が)⟯, the ones ⟮c+;ending -eru⟯ (that is, ⟮c+;ける and れる⟯) are ⟮c+;transitive (を)⟯
⟮c+;十一日⟯ is pronounced ⟮c+;じゅういちにち⟯&nbsp;&nbsp;<div class="sub"> for day counting, beyond 10 readings become pretty normal, except that 四日 is still read よっか and 九 is generally read く </div>
for day counting, ⟮c+;beyond 10⟯ readings become ⟮c+;pretty normal⟯, except that ⟮c+;四日 is still read よっか⟯ (but mostly ⟮c+;only for calendar days⟯, it generally becomes ⟮c+;regular after 30⟯) and ⟮c+;九 is generally read く⟯
while counting ⟮c+;days⟯ ⟮c+;ordinally⟯ with ⟮c+;<span style="color: rgb(55, 58, 60);">第somenumber</span>日⟯&nbsp;⟮c+;forces the whole thing into 漢語 numbers⟯, ⟮c+;somenumber日目⟯ ⟮c+;leaves them as-is (compared to their normal readings, i.e. 2-9 will be read with か etc.)⟯
⟮c+;第六日⟯ is read ⟮c+;だいろくにち⟯        <div class="sub"> because&nbsp;<span style="color: rgb(55, 58, 60);">第 forces the whole thing into kango for 日</span> </div>
⟮c+;四日目⟯ is read ⟮c+;よっかめ&nbsp;⟯<div class="sub"> since 目 doesn't change the reading </div>
&nbsp;⟮c+;四十九日⟯ is normally read as ⟮c+;よんじゅうくにち⟯. However, when it means "t⟮c+;he forty-ninth day after someone's death for the 49 Day Funeral Ceremony⟯", it is read as ⟮c+;しじゅうくにち⟯. 
the ⟮c+;和語 reading⟯ for ⟮c+;八⟯ is generally ⟮c+;や⟯, but for ⟮c+;8日⟯, which ⟮c+;over time turned into⟯ ⟮c+;よう⟯
more ⟮c+;rare⟯ readings for ⟮c+;一日⟯ as "⟮c+;one day⟯" include ⟮c+;いちじつ⟯ and ⟮c+;ひとひ⟯ (⟮c+;archaic⟯); for ⟮c+;一日⟯ as "⟮c+;the first day⟯" ⟮c+;いっぴ⟯ (mostly ⟮c+;business⟯ contexts)

⟮c+;お　凸（でこ）⟯&nbsp;= ⟮c+;brow, forehead⟯ ⟮c+;　凸（でこ）　凹（ぼこ）⟯ = ⟮c+;bumpy, lumpy, irregular, unequal, uneven⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b">may also be read とつおう</div> </div>
⟮c+;　凹凸（おうとつ）⟯ = ⟮c+;uneven, bumpy⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b">anagram of 凸凹 but never read with those readings</div> </div> ⟮c+;　電凸（でんとつ）⟯ = ⟮c+;flooding a company, organization etc. with phone complaints (usu. loosely organized on anonymous online message boards)⟯<div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b">from 　電話突撃（でんわとつげき）</div> </div> ⟮c+;　凸面（とつめん）⟯ = ⟮c+;convex surface⟯ ⟮c+;　凸（とつ）⟯&nbsp;= ⟮c+;convex (wenn der bauch...)⟯
⟮c+;　凹（おう）⟯ = ⟮c+;concave⟯ ⟮c+;　凹（おう）　面（めん）⟯ = ⟮c+;concave surface⟯
⟮c+;　巡（めぐ）る⟯ (may also be spelled <span class="c1-scr c2-scr">⟮c+;廻る⟯ or ⟮c+;回る⟯</span>) = ⟮c+;go around, circle, return, repeat, concern を⟯
⟮c+;　堂々巡（どうどうめぐ）り⟯&nbsp;= ⟮c+;going round in circles (do the same thign without progress)⟯
⟮c+;　堂々（どうどう）⟯&nbsp;= ⟮c+;magnificent, grand, impressive, dignified, fair, square, open, unreservex⟯
⟮c+;　巡（めぐ）らす⟯ = ⟮c+;enclose, build a barrier around, turn (e.g. one's head), work out を⟯
